titleStmt.title: The Gospel of Matthew - The Wycliff New Testament (Lichfield Cathedral)

div.p: Matheu that was of judee as he is set firs te in ordre of the gospeleris; so he wro ot firste the gospel in judee / and fro the offis of a tolgaderere he was clepis to god / wha ne this matheu hadde pchid firste the gos pel in judee, and wolde go to hethene men; he wroot firste the gospel in ebreu, and lefte it to mynde to cristen men of the jewis, fro whiche he departide bodili / for as it was nedeful, that the gospel were prechid to the confermynge of feith; so it was ne deful, that it were writen also aȝen ere tikes / thour many men han write the gos pel; foure oneli tht is, matheu, mark, luyk and joon, han the witnessyng of auto rite / for thei tellen the feith of the trinite; bi foure partis of the world / and thei ben as foure wheeles in the foure horsid carte of the lord; that berith hi aboute bi pre chyng of the gospel / and mankynde that was slayn bi foure dethis; schulde be kened bi the prechynge of hem/ and thfor the gospels of othe writeris felden dou, and ben not resseyued; for the lord nolde that the forseid noubre were distried, for the vertu of sacrament / Also the foure gospe leris ben undurstonden bi foure figuris of gostli pryuytee / matheu is undurston den bi man; for he dwellith principali a boute the manheed of crist / mark is undur stonden bi aliou; for he tretith of crist risynge aȝen/ luyk is undurstonden bi a calf; and tretith of presthood/ Joon is undur stonden bi an egle; and writith hizlier the sa cramentis eith hooli puytees of the godhed / forsothe crist whom these gospeleris discri uen; was a man boren of the virgyn / he was a calf, in offryng eith diynge on the cross / he was a liou; in risyng aȝen/ and he was an egle in assenciou / eith the manheed of crist is signefied in many / presthood is signefied in the calf, rewme is signefied in the liou; and the sacrament of godhed i the egle / that is, bi these foure beestis it is de clarid; that jhu crist is god and ma kyng and prest /
The book of the generaciou of Jhu Crist; the sone of Dauith the sone of Abraham /
Abraham bigat ysaar. ysaar bigat Jacob / Jacob bigat uidas and hise brithen /
judas bigat phares and ȝaram, of thamar / phares bigat esrom /
es rom bigat aram / aram bigat amynadab / amynadab bigat naason / naason bigat salmon /
salmon bigat booȝ of raab / booȝ bigat obeth of ruth / obeth bigat jesse / jesse bigat Dauith the kyng /
Dauith the kyng bigat salomon of hir that was vries wijf /
salomon bigat ro boam / roboam bigat abias /
abias bigat asa / asa bigat josaphath / josaphath bigat joram / joram bigat
osias / osias bigat Joatha / joathan bigat achaȝ / achaȝ bigat eȝechie /
eȝechie bigat manasses / manasses bigat a mon /
amon bigat josias / josias bigat jero nyas and hise brithen in to the transmygraciou of babiloyne /
and aftir the transmygracioun of babiloyne, jeronyas bigat salatiel / sala tiel bigat ȝorobabel /
ȝorobabel bigat abuid / abyud bigat eliachym / eliachym bigat a sor /
asor bigat sadoch / sadoch bigat achym /
achym bigat eluid / elyud bigat eliaȝar / eliaȝar bigat mathan /
mathan bigat ja cob / jacob bigat joseph the hosebonde of marie; of whom jhr was boren, that is clepid crist

And so alle generacious fro Abraham to Dauith ben fourtene generaci ous / and from Dauith to the transmygraciou of babiloyne; ben fourtene generacious / and fro the transmygraciou of babiloyn to Crist; ben fourtene generaciouns /
but the generacioun of crist was thus. Whane marie the modir of jhu was spousid to jo seph; bifore thei camen togidere, sche was founden hauynge of the hooli goost in the wombe /
and joseph hir hosebonde for he was riȝtful and wolde not pupplisthe hir; he wolde pryueli haue lefte hir /

but whi le he bithouȝte these thingis; lo the augel of the lord apperide `in sleep to hi and seide / joseph the sone of Dauith; nyle thou drede to take Marie thi wij / for that thing that is borun in hir; is of the hooli goost /
And sche schal bere a sone; and thou schalt clepe his name Jhr / for he schal make his puple saaf fro her synnes /
For al this thing was doon, that it schulde be fulfillid that was seid of the Lord bi a pphete seiynge / lo
a virgyn schal haue in wombe, and sche sch al bere a sone, and thei schulen clepe his na me emanuel that is to seie god with us /
and Joseph roos fro sleep, and dide as the aungel of the Lord comaudide hi, and he took Marie his wijf /
and he knew hir not til sche hadde borun her firste bigetu sone; and clepide his name Jhr /
Therfor whane Jhr was boru in beth leem of juda, in the daies of kyng heroude; lo astronomyens camen fro the eest to Jerlin,
and seiden / Where is he that is borun kyng of Jewis / for we han seyn his sterre in the eest; and we comen for to worschipe hym /
But kyng eroude herde, and was troblid; and al Jerlm with hi /
And he gaderide togidere alle the prynces of pstis, and scribis of the puple; and enqueride of he, where crist schulde be boren /
And thei sei den to hi / in bethleem of juda / forsothe it is writen bi a pphete /
and thou bethleem the lond of Juda, art not the leest among the prynces of Juda / for of thee a duyk schal go out; that schal goime my puple of Is rael /
thane eroude clepide pryueli the as tronomyenes; and lernyde of hem bisili the tyme of the sterre that apperide to hem /
And he sente hem in to bethleem; and seide / go ȝe and axe ȝe bisili of the child / and wha ne ȝe han foundun, telle ȝe it to me; that I also come and worschipe hi /
And whane thei hadden herd the kyng; thei wenteforth and lo the sterre that thei saien in the eest wente bifore hem; til it cam and stood a boue, where the child was /
And thei saien the sterre; and ioieden with a ful greet ioie /

And thei entriden in to the hous; and foude the child with Marie his modir / and thei felden dou; and worschipiden hi / and whane thei hadden openyde her tresouris; thei offri den to hym ȝiftis, gold, encense and myrre /
And whane thei hadden take an answere in sleep; that thei schulden not turne a ȝen to eroude, thei turneden aȝen bi an othe weie in to her cuntree.

P And whane thei weren goon; lo the aungel of the lord, apperide to joseph in sleep, and seide / rise up and take the child and his modir and fle in to egipt / And be thou there til that I seie to thee / for it is to come; that eroude seke the child to destrie hym /
And joseph roos; and took the child and his modir bi nyȝt and wente in to egipt /
and he was the to the deeth of eroude / that it schulde be fulfillide that was seid of the Lord bi the pphete seiynge / fro egipt I haue clepid my sone /

Thaue he roude seynge that he was disseyued of the astronomyenes; was ful wrooth / and he sente and slowe alle the children that we ren in bethleem, and in alle the coostis the of / fro two ȝeer age and with me; aftir the ty me that he hadde enqueride of the astro myenes /
Thanne it was fulfillide that was seid bi the pphete
seiynge / A vois was herd an hiȝ, wepynge and myche weilyng, rachel biwepynge hir sones; and sche wolde not be comfortide, for thei ben not.
But wha ne heroude was deed; lo the aungel of the Lord apperide to Joseph in sleep in e gipt
Joseph roos, and took the child and his mo dir and cam in to the lond of Israel /
And he herde that Archilawes regnyde in Judee for eroude his fadir; and dredde to go thidur / And he was warned in sleep; and wente in to the partis of Galilee /
N tho daies joon baptist cam; and pchide in the desert of judee
and seide / Do ȝe penauce; for the kyngdom of heuenes schal neiȝ /
for this is he of whom it is seid bi ysaie, the pphete, seyinge / a vois of a criere in desert / make ȝe redi the weies of the lord; make ȝe riȝt the pathis of hym /
and this joon hadde clo thing of camelis heeris; and a girdil of skyn aboute hise leendis / and his meete was honysoukis and hony of the wode /
thane je rusalem wente out to hi and al judee, and al the cuntree aboute jordan;
and thei weren waischen of hym in jordan, and knoulechide her synnes /
But he siȝ many of the farisees and of saduceis comynge to his baptym, and seide to hem / generaciouns of eddris; who shewide to ȝou to fle fro wraththe that is to come /
therfor do ye worthi fruyte of pe nauce;
and nyle ȝe seie with me ȝou, we ha Abraham to fadir / for I seie to ȝou, that god is myȝti to reise up of these stoones; the so nes of Abraham /
And now the axe is put to the roote of the tree / thefor eueri tree that makith not good fruyt; schal be kit dou and schal be caste in to the fier /
I waische ȝou in watir; in to penaunce / but he that schal come aftir me, is stronger than I; whos schoon I am not worthi to beere; he shal baptise ȝou in the hooli goost and fier /
Whos wynewyng cloth is in his hond; and he schal fulli clense his corn floor / and schal ga dere his wheete in to his berne; but the chaf he schal brenne with fier that mai not be quenchid.
Thanne jhr cam fro galilee in to jordan to joon; to be baptisid of hi /
And joon forbede hi; and seide / I owe to be baptiside of thee; and thou comest to me ⁝/
but jhu answeride; and seide to hym / suffre now / for thus it fallith to us to fulfille al riȝtfulnesse /

thanne joon suffride hi / and whane jhu was baptisid; a noon he wen te up fro the watir / and lo heuenes were openyde to hym; and he say the spirit of god comynge dou as a dowue; and comynge on hi / and lo
a vois fro heuenes; seiynge / this is my loued sone; in which I haue plesid to me /
Thanne jhr was lad of a spirit in to desert; to be temptid of the fend /
and whane he hadde fastid fourti daies and fourti nyytis; aftirward he hungride /
and the tempter cam nyȝ; and seide to hi / if thou art goddis sone; seie that these stoones be maad looues /
which answeride and seide to hym / It is writen / not oneli in breed lyueth man; but in ech word that cometh of goddis mouth /
thanne the fend took hi in to the hooli citee; and settide hi on the pi nacle of the temple,

and seide to hi / if thou art goddis sone; sende thee a dou / for it is writen / that to hise augels he comau dide of thee; and thei schulen take thee in hondes, lest parauenture thou hirte thi foot at a stoon /
estesoone jhr seide to hi / It is writen / thou schalt not tempte thi lord god /
and seide to hi / alle these I schal yyue to thee; if thou falle doun and worschipe me /
thanne jhr sei de to hi / go sathanas / for it is writu / thou schalt worschipe thi lord god; and to hi aloo ne thou shalt serue /
thane the fend lefte hi / and lo augels camen nyȝ; and seruyde to hym.
But whane jhr hadde herd that joon was taken; he wente in to galilee /
and he lefte the citee of naȝareth; and cam and dwelte in the citee of capharnau bisidi the see in the coostis of ȝabulon and neptali /
that it shulde be fulfillid, that was seid bi ysaie the pphete seiynge /
the lond of ȝa bulon, and the lond of neptalym the weie of the see ouer jordan of galilee of hethe ne men
fro that tyme jhr bi gan to preche and seie / Do ye penauce; for the kyngdom of heuenes schal come nyȝ /
And jhr walkide bisidis the see of galilee; and sai twei brithen / symount that is clepid petir and andreu his broth castynge nettis in to the see / for thei weren fischeris /
and he seide to hem / come ȝe aftir me; and I schal make ȝou to be maad fisscheris of men /
And a noon thei leften the nettis; and sueden hym /
And he ȝedeforth fro that place; and say tweyne othe brithen, james of ȝebedee and joon his broth in a schip wt ȝebedee her fadir amendynge her nettis, and he clepide hem /
And a noon thei leften the nettis and the fadir; and sueden hi /
and jhr ȝede aboute al galilee techynge in the synagogis of hem, and prechynge the gos pel of the kyngdom and heelynge euy lan gore and eche sikenesse among the puple /

and his fame; wente in to al sirie / and thei brouȝten to hi alle that weren at ma le eese, and that weren take with dyurse lan gores and turmentis / and hem that hadde fendis, and lunatik men, and men in the pa lesie, and he heelide hem /
And the sueden hi myche puple of galilee / and of decapoli and of jerlim, and of judee and of biȝoude jordan /
And jhu seynge the puple, wente up in to an hil / and whanne he was set; hise disciplis camen to hi /
And he o penyde his mouth and tauȝte hem and seide /
Blessed be pore men in spirit; for the kig dom of heuenes is hern /
blessid be myl de men; for thei schulen welde the erthe /
blessid ben thei that morenen; for thei schu len be comfortid /
blessid ben thei that hu gren and thristen riȝtfulnesse; for thei schule be fulfillid /
blessid be merciful men; for thei schulen gete merci /
blessid be thei that ben of cleene herte; for thei schulen se god /
blessid be pesible men; for thei schu len be clepid goddis children /
blessid be thei that suffren pseaiciou for riȝtfulnesse; for the kyngdom of heuenes is hern /
ȝe schulen be blessid whane men schule cur se you and schulen pursue you, and schulen seie al yuel aȝen ȝou, liyuge for me /
Ioie ȝe and be ȝe glade; for ȝoure meede is plenteuouse in heuenes for so thei han pursued pphetis that weren bifore you.
Ze ben salt of the erthe / that if the salt vanysche awei; wher ine schal it be saltid / to no thing it is worth ouer; but that it be cast out and be defoulide of men /
ȝe ben liȝt of the world / a citee set on an hil; mai not be hid /
ne me tendith not a lanterne and puttith it undur a busshel, but on a candilstike that it ȝyue liȝt to alle that ben in the hous /
so schyne ȝoure liȝt bifore men, that thei se ȝoure good wer kis; and glorifie ȝoure fadir that is in heue nes.
Nile ȝe deme that I cam to undo the lawe or the pphetis / I cam not to undo the lawe; but to fulfille /
forsothe I seie to you, til heuene and erthe passe, o lettir or o ti tel, schal not passe fro the lawe til alle thig be doon /

thefor he that brekith oon of these leeste maundementis and techith thus men; schal be clepid the leste in the rewme of heuenes / but he that doith and techith; schal be clepid greet in the kyngdom of heu enes.
And I seie to you, that but if ȝoure riȝtfulnesse be more plenteuouse than of scribis and of farisees; ye schulen not entre into the kyngdom of heuenes /
ȝe han herd that it was seid to elde men; thou schalt not slee / and he that sleeth; schal be gilti to dom /

But I seie to you, that ech man that is wrooth to his broth; schal be gilti to doom / and he that seith to his brother, Fyi schal be gilti to the councel / but he that seith fool; schal be gilti to the fier of helle /

Be thou consentynge to thi adusa rie soone while thou art in the weie with hym; lest parauenture thi aduersarie take thee to the domesman / and the domes man take thee to the mynystre and thou be set in to prisoun /
treuli I seie to thee, thou schalt not go out fro theun; til thou ȝelde the las te ferthyng.
Ze han herd that it was seid to olde men; thou schalt not do lercherie /
but I seie to you, that euery man that seeth a woman to coueite hir; hath now do ler cherie bi hir in his herte /
that if thi riȝt iȝe sclaundre thee; pulle hym out and caste fro thee / for it spedith to thee, that oon of thi membris perische; than that al thi bodi go in to helle /
and if thi riȝthond sclaudre thee; kitte hi awei and caste fro thee / for it spedith to thee that oon of thi membris perische; than that al thi bodi go in to hel le.
And it hath be seid / who euere leeueth his wijf; ȝyue he to hir a libel of forsa kyng /
but I seie to you, that eueri ma that leeueth his wijf, outaken cause of fornycaciou; makith hir to do lercherie / and he that weddith the forsaken wijf; doith auoutrie.
Efresoone ye han herd that it was seid to olde men; thou schalt not forswere, but thou schalt ȝelde thi othes to the lord /
But I seie to ȝou that ȝe swere not for ony thing / neith bi heuene; for it is the troone of god /
for thou maist not make oon heer white neith blak /
but be ȝoure word ȝhe ȝhe nai nai; and that that is more tha these, is of yuel.
Ze han herd that it hath ben seid; iȝe for iȝe and tooth for tooth /
but I seie to you, that ye aȝenstonde not an yuele man / but if ony smyte thee in the riȝt cheke; schewe to hi also the toth /
and to hi that wole stryue with thee in doom and take awei thi roote; leeue thou to hym also thi mantil /
and who eue co streyneth thee a thousynde pacis; go thou with hi othe tweyne /
ȝyue thou to hi that axith of thee; and turne not awei fro hi that wole borewe of thee.
Ze han herd that it was seid, thou schalt loue thi neiybore; and hate thyn enemye /
but I seie to you / loue ȝe ȝoure enemyes, and do ȝe wel to hem that hatiden ȝou, and preie ȝe for he that pursuen, and sclaundren you,
for if ȝe louen hem that louen you; what meede schulen ȝe ha ue ⁝/ Wheth pupplicans doon not this /
and if ȝe greeten ȝoure brithen oneli; what schulen ȝe do more ⁝/ ne doon not hethene men this ⁝/
thefor be ye parfit; as youre heuenlifadir is parfite /
Takith heede that ȝe do not ȝoure riȝt fulnesse bifore men to be seyn of he, ellis ȝe schulen haue bo meede at ȝoure fadir that is in heuenes /
thefor whane thou doist almes; uyle thou trumpe bifore thee as ypocritis doon in synagogis and in stre tis, that thei be worschipid of men / sotheli I seie to you; thei han resseyuede her mee de /
but whanne thou doist almes; knowe not thi lefte hond what thi riȝthond doith,
that thi almes be in hidlis / and thi fadir that seeth in hidlis schal guyte thee /
and whanne ȝe preien; ȝe schulen not be as ypocritis that louen to preie stondige i synagogis and corneris of stretis to be sey of men / treuli I seie to ȝou, thei han res seyeude her meede /
but whane thou schalt preie; entre in to thi couche, and whane the dore is schit, preie thi fadir in hidlis / and thi fadir that seeth in hidlis; schal ȝel de to thee /
thefor nyle ȝe be maad lijk to hem / for ȝou re fadir woot what is nede to ȝou bi fore that ȝe axen hi /
and thus ȝe schule preie / Oure fadir that art in heunes; halewid be thi name /
thi kyngdom come to / be thi wille doon in erthe; as in heuene /
ȝy ue to us this dai ore breed ouer othe sub staunce /
and forȝyue to us oure dettis; as we forgyuen to oure dettouris /
and le de us not in to temptaciou; but delyuere us from yuele amen /
for if ȝe forȝyuen to men her synnes; ȝoure heuenli fadir schal forȝyue to ȝou ȝoure trespassis /
so theli if ȝe forȝyuen not to men; neith ȝou re fadir schal forȝyue to ȝou ȝoure synes //
But whanne ȝe falten; nyle ȝe be maad as ypocritis soreuful / for thei defacen he silf to seme fastynge to men / treuli I seie to ȝou; thei han resseyued her meede /
but whane thou fastist anoynte thi heed and waische thiface;
Nile ȝe tresoure to ȝou tre souris in erthe; Where rust and mouyte dis troieth, and where theues deluen out and steele /
but gadere to you tresouris in heuene; where neith rust ne mouȝte distrieth, and where theues deluen not out ne steele /
for where thi tresour is; there also thyji herte is.
The lanterne of thi bodi; is thi iȝe / if thyi iȝe be symple; al thi bodi schal be liȝtful /
but if thyn iȝe be weiward; al thi bodi schl be derk / if thanne th liȝt that is in thee, be derknessis; hou greet schu len thilke derknessis be.
No man mai ser ue tweyne lordis / for eith he schal hate the toon and loue the toth; erth he schal sustey ne the toon, and dispise the toth / ȝe mou not serue god and richesse /
thefor I seie ȝou, that ȝe be not bisi to ȝoure lijf, what ȝe schulen ete neith to ȝoure bodi with what ȝe schulen be dothid / where lijf is not mo re than mete; and the bodi more than clooth ⁝/
biholde ȝe the foules of the eir, for thei sowe not neth repen neith gaderen in to bernes; and ȝoure fadir of heuene fedith hem / Wher ȝe ben not more worthi than thei ⁝/
but who of ȝou thenkynge, mai put to his stature, o cubit;
and I seie to you, salomon in al his glorie was not kyuerid as oon of these /
and if god clothith thus the hei of the feeld, that to dai is and to morewe is caste in to an ouene; hou myche more you of litil feith ⁝/
thefor nyle ȝe be bisy seiynge / what schulen we ete or what schulen we drynke; or with what thing schulen we be kyuerid ⁝/
for hethene men seken al le these thingis, and ȝoure fadir woot that ȝe han nede to alle these thingis /
therfor seke ȝe fwste the kyngdom of god and his riȝtful nesse; and alle these thingis schulen be caste to you /
thefor nyle ȝe be bisi in to the more we / for the morewe schal be bisi to hiself / for it sufficith to the dai his owne malice /
Nile ȝe deme; and ȝe schulen not be de med /
for in what doom ȝe demen; ȝe schulen be demed / and in what mesure ȝe meten; it schal be meten aȝen to you /
but what leeft thou a litil mote, in the iȝe of thi broth; and leeft not a beem in thi owne iȝe /
or hou seist thou to thi brother, broth suffre I schal do out a mote fro thyn iȝe and lo a beem is in thi owne iȝe ⁝/
ypocrite do out firste the beem of thi iȝe; and thane thou schalt se to do out the moote of the iȝe of thi broth.
Nile ȝe ȝyue hooli thing to houdis, neth caste ȝe ȝoure marga ritis bifore swyn / lest parauenture thei defoulen hem with her feet / and the houdes be turned and al to tere ȝou.
Axe ȝe; and it schal be ȝouen to ȝou / seke ȝe; and ȝe schu len fynde / knocke ȝe; and it schal be ope nyde to ȝou /
for ech that axith; takith / and he that sekith; fyndith / and it schal be ope ned to hym; that knockit /
what man of you is, that if his sone axe hi breed; wheth he wole take hi a stoon ⁝/
or if he axe fisch, wheth he wole take hi an eddir ⁝/
thefor if ȝe whanne ȝe ben yuele men kunen ȝyue good ȝiftis to ȝoure sones; hou myche more ȝoure fadir that is in heuenes schal ȝyue good thingis to men that axen hi ⁝/
thefor al le thingis what euere thingis ȝe wolen that men do to ȝou; do ȝe to hem / for this is the lawe and the pphetis.
Entre ȝe bi the streiȝt ȝate / for the ȝate that ledith to perdicioun is large; and the weie is brood / and the ben manye that entren bi it /
hou streiȝt is the ȝate and narowe the weie that ledith to lijf; and the ben few that fynden it.
Be ȝe war of false prhetis that comen to ȝou in clo thyngis of scheep; but with meforth thei be wolues of raueyn /
of her fruytis ȝe schu len knowe hem / wheth men gaderen gra pis of thoȝnes or figes of breris ⁝/
So eueri good tree; makith good fruytis / but an yue le tree; makith yuele fruytis /
a good tree mai not make yuele fruytis; neith an y uele tree make good fruytis /
eueri tree that makith not good fruyt; schal be kit dou and schal be caste in to the fier /
thefor of her fruytis; ye schulden knowe hem /
not ech man. that seith to me lord lord; shal entre in to the kyngdom of heuenes / but he that doith the wille of my fadir that is in heue nes; he shal entre in to the kyndgom of heuenes;
many schulen seie to me in that dai, lord lord wheth we han no prhesied in thi name, and han caste out fendis in thi name, and han doon many vertues in thi na me ⁝/
and thanne I schal knouleche to hem; that I knew you neue / departe awei fro me; ȝe that worchen wickidnesse.
Therfor ech man that herith these my wordis and doith hem; schal be maad lijk to a wise man that hath bildid his on a stoon /
and reyn felle doun and floodis camen and wyndis blewe and ruschiden in to that hous and it felde not dou, for it was foudide on a stoon /
and e ueri man that herith these my wordes and doith hem not; is lijk to a fool that hath bil did his hous on grauel /
and reynes cam dou and floodis camen and wyndis blewen and thei hurliden aȝen that hous; and it felde dou, and the fallyng the of was greet /
and it was doon whane Jhu hadde endid these wordis; the puple wondride on his techyng /
for he tauȝte hem as he that hadde power; and not as the scribis of hem and pharisees /
But whanne Jhr was comen dou fro the hil; myche puple suede hi /
and seide lord if thou wolt; thou maist make me cleene
and jhr helde forth the hond; and touchide hi and seide / I wole be thou maad cleene / and a noon the lepre of hym was clensid /
and jhr seide to hym / se, seie thou to no man; but do sche we thee to the prestis, and offre the ȝifte that moises comaudide in witnessyng to hem //
And whane he hadde entrid in to capharnau; the centurien neiȝide to hi, and preiede hi
and seide / lord my child liyth on the hous, sijk on the pa lesie; and is yuel turmentid /
and jhr seide to hym / I schal come and schal heele hi /
and the centurien answeride; and seide to hym / lord I am not worthi that thou entre undur my roof / but oneli seie thou bi word; and my child shal be heelid /
for whi I am a man ordeynede un our power and have kuyȝtis undir me / and I seie to this go; and he goith / and to anothe co me; and he cometh / and to my seruaunt to this; and he doith it /
and jhr herde these thingis; and wondride / treuli i seie to ȝou; I foond not so greet feith in israel /
and i seie to you, that manye schulen come fro the eest and the west; and schulen reste with abraham Isaar and ja cob in the kyngdom of heuenes /
but the so nes of the rewme; schulen be cast out in to utmere derknessis / the schal be wepyng and gryntyng of teeth /
and jhr seide to the centu rien / go; and as you hast bileued, be it doon to thee / and the child was heelid fro that our //
and he touchide hir hond; and the feuer lefte hir / and sche roos and seruyde hem /
that it were fullide that was seid bi ysaie the pphete seiynge / he took oure infirmytees; and bar oure sikenessis.
And jhr sai myche puple aboute hi; and bad his disciplis go ouer the watir /
and a scribe neiȝide; and seide to hym / maistir i schal sue thee whidir euere thou schalt go /
and jhr seide to hi / foxis han den nes and briddis of heuene han neestis; but mann sone hath not where he schal reste his heed /
An othe of his disciplis seide to hi / lord suffre me to go firste and birie my fadir /
but jhr seide to hi / sue thou me; and lete deed men birie her deed men /
and whane he was goon up in to a litil schup; hise disciplis sueden hi /
and lo a greet stiryng was maad in the see; so that the schip was hilid with wawis / but he slept /
and hise disciplis camen to hi; and reisiden hi and seide / lord saue us; we perischen /
and jhr seide to hem / what be ȝe of litil feith a gast / thanne he roos and comaudide to the wyndis and the see; and a greet pesiblenesse was maad /
and men wondriden and seiden / what maner man is he this; for the wyndis and the see obeschen to hym.
And whanne jhu was comen ouer the watir in to the cutre of men of gerasa; twei men metten hym that hadden deuelis and camen out of gra ues ful wood, so that no man myȝte go bi that weie /
and lo thei crieden and seiden / wht to us and to thee jhu the sone of go ⁝/ art thou comen hidur bifore the tyme to turmente us ⁝/
and not for fro hem was a flokke of manye swyne lesewynge /
and the deuelis praieden hym and seiden / if thou castist us out from hennes; sende us in to the droue of swyn /
and he seide to he / go ȝe / and thei ȝeden out, and wenten into the swyn / and lo in a greet bire, al the droue wente heedlig in to the see; and thei weren deed inthe wa tris /
and the herdis fledden awei, and came in to the citee, and telden alle these thingis and of hem that hadden the fendis /
and lo al the citee wente out aȝen jhu / and whane thei hadden seyn hym; thei preieden that he wolde pas se fro her coostis /
And jhr wente up in to a boot and passi de the wat and cam in to his citee;
and lo thei brouȝten to hym a man sijk in palesie; liggynge in a bed / and jhr siȝ the feith of he and seide to the man sijk in palesie / sone ha ue thou trist; thi synnes ben forȝouen to thee /
and lo sume of the scribis; seiden withme hem silf / this blasphemeth /
and whane jhu hadde seyn her thouȝtis; he seide / wher to thenke ȝe yuele thingis in ȝoure hertis ⁝/
what is it liȝter to seie thi synnes be for ȝouen to thee; eith to seie rise thou and walke /
but that ȝe wite that man sone hath po wer to forȝyue synnes in erthe / thanne he seide to the sijk man in palesie / rise up; and take thi bed and go in to thi hous /
and he roos; and wente in to his hous /
and the puple se ynge dredde and glorifiede god that ȝat such power to men.
And whane jhr passide fro them; he sai a man matheu bi name sit tynge in a tolbothe / and he seide to hym / sue thou me / and he roos and folewide hym /
and it was doon, the while he sat at the me te in the hous; lo manye pupplicans and synful men camen and saten at the mete with jhu and hise disciplis /
and farisees sien; and seiden to hise disciplis / whi etith ȝoure mais ter with pupplicans ad synful men ⁝/
and jhr herde and seide / a leche is not nedeful to men that faren wel; but to men that be yuele at ese /
but go ȝe and lerne ȝe what it is; I wole merci and not sacrifice / for I cam not to clepe riȝtful men; but synful me.
Thanne the disciples of joon camen to hi and seiden / whi we and farisees fasten ofte; but thi disciplis fasten not ⁝/
and jhr seide to hem / wher the sones of the spouse mou morne; as longe as the spouse is with he / but daies schulen come whane the spouse schal be taken awei fro hem; and thane thei shu len faste /
and no man putith a cloute of b buystouse clooth in to an olde clothyng / for it doith awei the fulnesse of the cloth; and a wer se brekynge is maad /
neith men putten ne we wyn in to olde botelis / ellis the botels ben to broke and dearied and the wyn sched out / but men putten newe wyn in to newe bo telis; and bothe ben kept.
Whiles that jhu spak these thingis to hem; lo a prynce cam and worschipide hym and seide / lord my douȝt is now deed; but come thou an put thin hond on hir, and sche schal lyue /
and jhu roos and hise disciplis; and sueden hi /
and lo a woma that hadde ablodi flur twelue ȝee; neiȝide bihynde and touchide the heme of his cloth /
sche seide with me hir self / if I touche one li the clooth of hym; I schal be saaf /
and the woman was hool fro that our /
and whane jhr cam in to the hous of the prynce and sai mynstrals and the puple makynge noise;
he seide / go ȝe awei / for the damesele is not deed; but clepith / and thei scorneden hi /
and whane the folk was put out; he wente me and helde hir hond, and the damesele roos up /
and this fame wente out in to al that lond.
And whanne jhr passide fro them twei blynde men criynge sueden him and seiden / thou sone of dauith haue merci on us /

and whanne he cam in to the hous; the blynde men camen to hym / and jhr seide to hem / what wolen ȝe that I do to ȝou / and thei sei den / lord; that oure iȝen be opened / and jhr seide / blileuen ȝe that i mai do this thing to ȝou ⁝/ thei seien to hym / ȝhe lord /
thanne he touchide her iȝen and seide / aftir ȝoure feith; be it doon no ȝou /
and the iȝen of he we ren openyde / and jhr thretenyde hem and seide / se ȝe that no man wite /
but thei ȝe den out and diffameden hym thorouȝ al that lond //
And whanne thei weren goon out; lo thei brouȝten to hym a doube man ha uynge a deuel /
and whanne the deuel was cast out; the dumb man spak / and the puple wondride and seide / it hath not be seyn thus in israel /
but the pharisees seiden / in the prynce of deuelis he castith out deuelis //
And jhr wente aboute al the citees and cas tels; techynge in synagogis of hem / and prechyng the gospel of the kyngdom; and hee lynge eueri langour and eueri sikenesse /
and he liȝ the puple and hadde reuthe on hem; for thei weren trauelid and liggynge as scheep not hauynge aschepparde /
thanne he seide to hise disciplis / sotheli the is myche ripe corn; but fewe werk men /
thefor preie ȝe the lord of the ripe corn; that he sende werke men in to his ripe corn /
And whanne his twelue disciplis we ren clepid togidere; he ȝaf to hem power of uncleene spiritis, to caste hem out of men, and to heele eueri langour and sikenesse /
and these ben the names of the twelue apostlis / the firste symout that is named petre and andreu his broth / james of ȝebedee; and joon his broth /
filip and bar tholomew, thomas and matheu pupplican, james alfey and thadde,
symout cananee, and judas scarioth that bitraiede crist /
but rathe go ȝe to the scheep of the hous of israel that han perischid /
and go ȝe and preche ȝe and seie, that the kyngdom of heunes schal neiȝ /
hele ȝe sijk men seise ȝe deed men clen se ȝe mesels caste ȝe out deuelis / freli ȝe han taken; freli ȝyue ȝe /
uyle ȝe welde gold neith siluer ne monei in ȝoure gir dlis,
not a scrippe in the weie, neith twei rootis, neith schoon, neith aȝerde / for a werk man is worthi his mete /
in to wht euere citee or castel ȝe schulen entre; axe ȝe who the men is worthi and the dwelle ȝe til ȝe go out /
and whanne ȝe goon in (W004v Column 1) to an hows, grete ȝe it and seyn, thees to this hous /
and if thilke hous be worthi; ȝou re thees schal come on it / but if that hous be not worthi; ȝoure thees schal turne aȝen to ȝou /
and who eure resseyueth not ȝe, neith herith ȝoure wordes; go ȝe fro that hous or citee and spryuge of the dust of ȝoure feet /
treuli I seie to you, it schal be more suffe rable to the lond of men of sodom and of go mor in the dai of judgement; than to thilke citee.
lo I sende ȝou as scheep in the myd dil of wolues / thefor be ȝe sliȝ as serpentis; and symple as dwues /
but be ȝe war of men / for thei schulen take ȝou in her synagogis /
and to meiris or preadentis and kyngis ȝe schulen be lad for me; in witnessyng to hem and to the hethene men /
but whane thei take ȝou; nyle ȝe thenke hou or what thig ȝe schulen speke / for it schal be ȝouen to ȝou in that our what ȝe schulen speke /
for it be not ȝe that speken; but the spirit of ȝoure fadir that spekith in ȝou /
and the broth schal bitake the broth in the deth; and the fadir the sone / and sones schulen rise aȝen fadir and modir; and schulen turmente hem bi deth /
and ȝe schulen be in hate to alle men for my name / but he that schal dwelle stille in to the ende; schal be saaf
(and whane thei pur sue ȝou in this citee; fle ȝe in to an othe / treuli I seie to ȝou, ȝe schulen not ende the citees of israel; tofore mamr sone co me /
the disciple is not aboue the maistir; ne the seruaunt aboue his lord /
it is I now to the disciple; that he be as his maistir / and to the seruaunt; as his lord / if thei han cle pid the hosebonde man belȝebub; hou my che more his houshold meynee ⁝/
thefor dre de ȝe not hem ][for no thing is hid; that schal not be schewid / and no thing is thuy; that schal not be wist /
that thing that I seie to ȝou in derknessis; seie ȝe in the liȝt // and pche ȝe on housis that thing; that ȝe heren in the eere /
and nyle ȝe drede hem that mou sle the bodi; for thei mou not sle the soule / but ra there drede ȝe hym that mai leese bothe bodi and soule in to helle /
wheth twei sparewis ben not seeld for an halpeny; and oon of he schal not falle on the erthe withouten ȝoure fadir ⁝/
and alle the heeris of ȝoure heed ben noubrid /
thefor nyle ȝe drede; ȝe ben betere than many sparewis /
therfor eueri man that schal knouleche me bifore men; I schal knou leche hi bifore my fadir that is in heuenes][
but he that schal denye me bifore me; and I schal denye hym bifore my fadir that is in heuenes. ][
Nile ȝe deme that I cam to sende thees in to erthe / I cam not to sende thees; but swerd /
for I cam to departe a man aȝen his fadir; and the douȝtir aȝen hir modir, and the sones wijf aȝen the hosebondis modir /
and the enemyes of a man ben thei that ben homeli with hym.
He that loueth fadir or modir more than me; is not worthi to me /
and he that takith not his crosse and sueth me; is not worthi to me /
he that fyndith his life; schal leese it / and he that leesith his lijf for me; schal fynde it /
he that resseyueth ȝou; resseyueth me / and he that resseyueth me; resseyueth hym that sente me /
and he that a pphete in the name of a pphete; schal take the meede of a pphete / and he that resseyueth a nist man in the na me of a nist man; schal take the ineede of a nist man /
And it was doon, whane jhr hadde endid; he comaundide to his twelue disciplis, and passide fro thenes to teche and preche in the citees of hem.
But whane joon in boondes hadde herd the werkis of crist; he sente tweyne of hise disciplis
and seide to hym / art thou he that schal come; or we abiden an othe ⁝/
and jhr answeride and seide to hem / go ȝe and telle aȝen to joon thoo thingis that ȝe han herd and seyn /
blynde me seen crokid men goon, mesels be maad clee ne, deef men heren, ded men risen aȝen, pore men ben taken to the prechyng of the gospel /
and he is blessid that schal not be sclaudrid in me /
and whane thei weren goon awei; jhr bigan to seie of joon to th puple / what thing wenten ȝe out in to the desert to se ⁝/ a rehed wawid with the wynd /
but what thing wenten ȝe out to se ⁝/ a pphete ⁝/ ȝhe and i seie to ȝou; and more than a pphete /
for this is he of whom it is written / lo I sende my aungel bifore thi face; that schal make re di thi weie bifore thee.
Treuli I seie to ȝou; the roos noon more than joon baptist amog the children of wymen / but he that is laste in the kyngdom of heuenes; is more than he /
and fro the daies of joon baptist til now; the kyngdom of heuenes suffrith violence, and violent men rauyschen it /
for alle pphe tis and the lawe til to joon ppherieden /
and if ȝe wolen resseeyue; he is elie that is to co me /
he that hath eeris of herynge; here he.
But to whom schal I gelle this gene raciou lijk ⁝/ it is lijk to children sittynge in chepyng; that crien to her peeris
and seie / we han sungen to ȝou; and ȝe han not dausid / we han morened to ȝou; and ȝe han not wei lid /
for joon cam neith etynge ne drynkige; and thei seien / he hath a deuel /
the sone of man cam etynge and drynkynge; and thei seien / lo a man a glotou and drynkere of wyn and freend of pupplicans and of synful men; and wisdom is justefied of her sones.
Thanne jhr bi gan to seie repreef to citees to whiche ful manye vertues of hi weren doon; for thei diden not penauce /
woo to thee corosaym, wo to thee bethsaida / for it the vertues that ben doon in ȝou hadden be doon in tire and sidon; sinn tyme thei hadden doon penauce in heire and aische /
netheles I seie to ȝou it schal be lasse peyne to tire and sidon in the dai of doom than to ȝou /

and thou capharnau weth thou schalt be arerid up in to heuene ⁝/ thou schal go dou in to helle / for if the vtues that han ben doon in theehadden be doon in sodom; parauenture thei schulden haue dwel lid in to this dai /
netheles I seie to ȝou, that to the lond of sodom it schal be lasse peyne in the dai of doom; than to thee.
In thilke out jhr answeride and seide / I knouleche to thee fadir lord of heuene and of erthe, for thou hast hid these thingis from wise men and redi; and hast schewide hem to litle children /
so fadir; for it was plesynge tofore thee /
alle thingis be ȝouen to me of my fadir / neith ony man knew the sone but the fadir / neith ony man knew the fadir but the sone; and to whom the sone wolde shewe /
alle ȝe that trauelen and be char gid come to me and i schal fulfille ȝou /
take ȝe my ȝok on ȝou and lerne ȝe of me for I am mylde and meke of herte; and ȝe schulen funde reste to ȝoure soules /
for my ȝok is softe; and my charge liȝt /
In that tyme jhr wente bi cornes in the sabat and hise disciplis hungriden and biguneu to plucke eeris of corn and to ete /
and farisees se ynge seiden to hym / lo thi disciplis doon that thing that is not leueful to hem to do in saba tis /
and he seide to hem / wheth ȝe han not red what dauith dide whane he hungride and thei that weren with hym ⁝/
and hou he en tride in to the hous of god, and ete looues of p poasiou / whiche looues it was not leueful to hi to ete, neith to hem that weren with hi; but to preestis aloone /
or wheth ȝe han not red in the lawe that in sabotis, prestis ni the temple defoulen the sabotis ⁝/ and thei ben with out blame /
and I seie to ȝou; that here is a grettere that than the temple /
and if ȝe wiste what it is, I wole merci and not sacrifice; ȝe schulen neue haue condempned more tis /
for mamr sone is lord ȝhe of the sabat
And whane he passide fro then; he cam in to the synagoge of hem /
and lo a man that hadde a drie hond / and thei ariden hi and sei den / wher it be leueful to heele in the sa both, that thei schulden accuse hi /
hou myche more is a man betere that a sche ep, thefor it is leueful to do good in the saba tis /
thanne he seide to the man / strerche forth thyn hond / and he strauȝte forth, and it was res torid to heelthe as the toth.
And the farisees wenten out and maden a counsel aȝen hi; thou thei schulden distrie hym /
and jhr knew it; and wente awei fro thenn / and manye sue den hi; and he heelide hem alle /
and he comau dide to hem that thei schulden not make hi knowen /
that that thing were fulfillid; that was seid bi ysaie the pphete seiynge /
lo my child whom I haue chosen; my derlyng i whom it hath wel plesid to my soule / I shal put my spirit on hym; and he schal telle dom to hethene men /
he schal not stryue ne crie; neith ouy man schal not breke /
and he schal not quenche smokynge fler til he cast out doom to victorie,
and hethene men schulen hope in his name /
thanne a man blynde and doumb that hadde a fend; was brouȝte to hi / and he hee lide hi; so that he spak and sai /
and al the pu ple wondride and saide / wheth this be the sone of dauith ⁝/
but the farisees herden and seiden / he this castith not out fendis but in belȝabub prynce of fendis /
and jhr witynge her thouȝ tis; seide to he / ech kyngdom departid aȝen it self; schal be desolatid / and ech citee or hous departid aȝen it silf; schal not stonde /
and if sathanas castith out sathanas; he is departid aȝen hi silf; thefor hou schal his kig dom stonde ⁝/
thanne the kyngdom of god is comen in to ȝou /
eith hou mai ony man entre in to the hous of a stronge man and take awei his vessels; but firste he bynde the stronge man, and thane he schal spuyle his hous /
he that is not with me; is aȝen me / and he that gaderith not togi dere with me; scaterith abrood /
thefor I seie to ȝou al synne and blasphemye schal be forȝoue to men; but the spirit of blasphemye schal not be forȝouen /
and who euere seith a word aȝen mann sone; it schal be forȝouen to hi / but who that seith a word aȝen the hooli gosst; it schal not be forȝouen to hi neithin this world ne in the toth /
eith make ȝe the tree good and his fruyt good; eith make ȝe the tree yuel and his fruyt yuel / for a tree is knowen of the fruyt /
ȝe generaciou of eddris; hou mou ȝe speke good thingis, whane ȝe ben yuele / for the mouth spekith of plente of the herte /
a good man bryngith forth good thingis of good tre sour /and an yuele man bryngith forth yue le thingis of of yuele tresour /
and i seie to ȝou / that of eueri idel word that men speke; thei schulen ȝelde resou the of in the dai of dom /
for of thi wordis thou schalt be justi fied; and of thi wordis thou schalt be dampned
Thanne sume of the scribis and farisees; answeriden to hi and seiden / maistir we wolen se a tokene of thee /
which answeri de and seide to hem / an yuele kyurede and aspou se brekere; sekith a tokene / and a tokene schal not be ȝouen to it; but the tokene of jonas the pphete /
for as jonas was inthe wo be of a whal there daise and there nyȝtis; so man sone schal be in the herte of the erthe there dai es and there nyȝtis /
men of nynyue schule ri se in doom with this generaciou and schulen co dempune it / for thei diden penauce in the pre chyng of jonas / and lo here a gretrir than jo nas /
the queene of the south schal rise i doom with this generaciou and schal condempne it; for sche cam fro the endis of the erthe to he re the wisdom of salomon / and lo here a gret tir than salomon /
whanne an uncleene spi rit goith out from a man; he goithbi drie places and sekith deste and fyndith not /

thanne he goith and takith with hym seuene othe spiritis worse than hym self; and thei entre and dwellen the / and the laste thingis of that man ben made worse than the formere / so it schal be to this worste generaciou /
rit while he spak to puple; lo his modir and hise brith en stroden without forth sekynge to speke to hi /
and a man seide to hi / lo thi modir and thi brithen stonden withoutenforth sekynge thee /
he answeride to the man that spak to hi; and seide / who is my modir; and who be my brithen ⁝/
and he helde forth his hond in to his disciplis; and seide / lo my modir and my brithen /
for who eue doith the wille of my fa dir that is in heuenes; he is my broth and sister and modir /
in that dai jhr ȝede out of the hous; and sat bisidis the see /
and myche puple was gade rid to hym; so that he wente up in to a boot and sat / and al the puple stood on the bryuke /
and he spak to hem manye thingis in para blis and seide / lo he that sowith; ȝede out to so we his seed /
and while he sowith; sume see dis felden bisidis the weie / and briddis of the eir camen; and eten hem /
but whanne the sune was risen; thei wa liden / and for thei hadden not roote; thei drie den up /
and othe seedis felde among thornes; and thornes woren up and stranliden hem /
but othe seedis felden in to good lond; and ȝaue fruyt, make an hundrid fold, an othe sisti fold, an othe thrittifold /
he that hath eeris of herynge; here he /
and the disciplis came nȝt and seiden to hi / whi spekist thou in pa rablis to hem /
for it schal be ȝouen to hi that hath; and he schal haue plentee / but if a man hath not; also that thing that he hath schal be taken awei fro hi /
that the ppherie of ysaie seiyuge be fulfillide in hem / with herynge ȝe schule here; and ȝe schulen not undurstonde / and ȝe se ynge schulen se; and ȝe schulen not se /

for the herte of this puple is gretli fattid; and thei li den heuyli with eeris / adn thei han not closid her iȝen; left su tyme thei seen with iȝen and with eeris heren and undurstonden in herte, and thei be couertid and i heele hem /
but ȝoure iȝen that seen be blessid; and ȝoure eeris that heren /
forsothe I seie to ȝou, that many pphetis and just men couertiden to se tho thingis that ȝe seen, and thei saien not / and to here tho thingis that ȝe heren; and thei herden not /
thefor here ȝe the parable of the sowere /
ech that herith the word of the rewne, and undurstondith not; the yuel spirit cometh and rauyschip that is sowe bisidis the weie /
but this that is sowen on the stony lond; this it is that herith the word of gos, and anoon with joie takith it /
but he that is sowen in thornes; is this that he rith the word, and the bisynesse of this world, and the fallace of richnessis stranglith the word, and it is maad withouten fruyt /
but he that is sowen in the good lond; is this that herith the word and undurstondith and bryngith forth fruyt / and sume makith an hundridfold treuli an othe sisti fold, and an othee thrittifold.
An othe parable jhr puttideforth to hem; and seide / the kyngdom of heuenes is maad lijk to a man that sew good seed in his feeld /
and whane me clepten, his enemye cam and sewe aboue, taa ris in the myddil of wheete and wente awei /
but whane the erbe was growid and maad fruyt; thane the taaris apperiden /
and the seruautis of the hosebonde man camen and seiden to hym / lord wher thou hast not sowe good seed in thi feeld; wher of thanne hath it taris ⁝/
and he seide to hem / an enemye hath doon this thing / and the seruauntis seiden to hym / wolt thou we goon and gaderen hem ⁝/
and he seide / nai / lest parauenture ȝe in gaderig taris drawen up with hem the wheete bi the roote /

suffre ȝe hem bothe were in to repig tyme, and in the tyme of the ripe corn, I schal seie to the reperis / firste gadere ȝe togidere the ta ris and bynde hem togidere in knyrchis to be brent; but gadere ȝe wheete in to my ber ne.
An othe parable jhr puttideforth to hem; and seide / the kyngdom of heuenes is lijk to a corn of seneuey, which a man took and sewe in his feeld,
which is the leest of alle seedis / but whane it hath woren; it is the moost of alle wortis, and is maad a tree / so that briddis of the eir comen and dwellen in the bowis the of //
An othe parable jhr spak to hem / the kyngdom of heuenes is lijk to sourdouȝ / which a woma took and hidde in there mesuris of mele; til it were al sourid /
jhr spak alle these thingis in parablis to the puple; and he spak not to he without parablis
that it schulde be fulfillid that is seid bi the pphete seiynge / I schal telle out hidde thingis fro the makynge of the world /
thanne he lefte the puple and cam in to an hous / and hise disciplis camen to hi; and seiden / er powne to us the parable of taaris of the feeld /
which answeride and seide / he that sowith good seed; is mann sone /
the feeld is the world / but the good seed; these be sones of the kyngdom / but taris these be yuele chil dren /
the enemye that sowith hem; is the fend / and the ripe corn; is the endyng of the world / the reperis ben aungels /
thefor as taaris be gaderid togidere and ben brent in fier; so it schal be in the endyng of the world /
man sone schal sende his augels and thei schulen gadere fro his rewme alle sclaudris and he that doon wickidnesse /
and thei schulen sende hem in to the chymeuei of fier; the schal be wepyng and betyng togidere of teeth /
thane just men schulen schyne as the sune in the rew me of her fadir / he that hath eeris of herige, here ȝe.

The kyngdom of heuenes is lijk to tresoure hid in a feeld / which a man that fyndith hidith, and for joie of it he goith and sillith alle thingis that he hath; and bieth thilke feeld // Jstesoones the kyngdom of heunes the kigdom of heuenes is lijk to a marchaut; that sekith good margaritis / but whane he hath founden o preciouse margarite; he wente and selde alle thingis that he hadde; and bouȝte it.
Efte the kyngdom of heuenes is lijk to a nette caste to the see, and that gaderith to gidere of alle kynde of fischis /
which wha ne it was ful thei drowen up and saten bi the brynke and chesen the good in to her vessels; but the yuele thei kesten out /
13: 50 and thei schulen sende hem in to the chymenei of fier / there schal be wepynge and gryntyng of teeth /
han ȝe undur stonden alle these thingis / thei seien to hi / ȝhe /
he seith to hem / thefor eueri wise man of la we in the kyngdom of heuenes is lijk to an hosebonde man that bryngith forth of his tre sour newe thing and elde. ][
And it was doon whanne jhr hadde endide these parablis; he passide fro thennes /
and he cam in to his cuntree and tauȝte hem in her synagogis, so that thei wondriden and seiden / fro whennes this wisdom and vertues
comen of a carpentere / wher his modir be not seid marie; and hise brithen ja mes and joseph and symout and judas /
and hise sistris; wheth thei ben not among us ⁝/ fro whennes alle these thingis comen to this ⁝/
and so thei weren sclaudrid in hi / but jhr seide to hem / a pphete is not withouten wor schip; but in his owne cuntree; and in his owne hous /
and he dide not the manye v tues; for the unbileue of hem /
In that tyme eroude tetrarck prynce of the fourthe part herde the fame of jhu;
and seide to his children / this is joon baptist / he is risun fro deth; and therfor vertues wor chen in hym /
for eroude hadde holde joon and bounden hi, and puttide hi in to prisou; for erodias the wijf of his broth /
for joon sei de to hym / it is not leueful to thee to haue hir /
and he willynge to sle hi, dredde the pu ple; for thei hadden hi as a pphete /
but in the dai of eroudis birthe, the douȝtir of erodias daunside in the myddil; and pleside eroude /
wherfor eure thing sche axide of hym /
and sche bifore warned of hir modir; seide / ȝyue thou to me the heed of joon baptist in a disch /
and the kyng was soreuful / but for the ooth, and for hem that saten togidere at the mete; he co maudide to be ȝouen /
and he sente; and bi hedid joon in the prisou /
and his heed was brouȝt in a disch; and it was ȝouen to the da mesele, and sche bar it to hir modir /
and hise disciplis camen; and token his bodi and biriede it / and thei camen and telden to jhu //
and whane jhr hadde herd this thing; he wente fro then in a boot in to desert place bisidis / and whane the puple hadde herd; thei folewiden hi on her feet fro citees //
And jhr ȝede out and sai a greet puple; and hadde reuthe on hem, and heelide the sijk of hem /
but whane the eue tide is come; hise disciplis camen to hi and seiden / the place is desert; and the tyme is now passid / late the puple go in to townes to bie hem mete /
jhr seide to hem / thei han not nede to go / ȝyue ȝe hem sumwhat to ete /
thei answeriden / we han not here; but fyue looues and twei fisches /
and he sei de to hem / brynge ȝe hem hidur to me /

and whane he hadde comaudide the pu ple to sitte to mete on the hey; he took fyue looues and twei fisches / and he bihel de in to heuene and blesside and brak and ȝaf to hise disciplis / and the disciplis ȝauen to the puple /
and alle eten and weren fulfil lide / and thei token the relifs of broku gobatis twelue coffyns ful /
and the nou (W008r Column 2) lyȝe of men that eten; was fyue thousynde of men outaken wymen and litle children.
And a noon jhr compellide the disciplis to go up in to a boot, and go bifore hym oer the see; while he lefte the puple /
and whane the puple was lefte; he stiede aloone in to an hil to preie / but whanne the euenyg was come; he was the aloone /
and the bo ot inthe myddil of the see; was contrarie to hem /
but in the fourthe wakyng of the nȝyt; he cam to hem walkynge aboue the see /
and thei synge hym walke on the see; weren disturblid and seiden that it is a fan tom / and for drede thei crieden /
and anoon jhr spak to hem and seide / haue ȝe triste I am; nyle ȝe drede /
and petre answeride and seide / lord if thou art; comaunde me to come thou /
and petre ȝede dou fro the bo ot and walkide on the watris, to come to jhu /
but he siȝ the wynd strong and was a feerd / and whanne he bigan to drenche; he crie de and seide / lord make me saaf /
and anoon jhr helde forth his hond; and took petre and seide to hi / thou of litil feith; whi hast thou doutide /
and whanne he hadde stied in to theboot; the wynd reesside /
and thei that weren in the boot; camen and worschipiden hi and sei den / verili thou art goddis sone //
And wha ne thei hadden passid oner the see; thei ca men in to the lond of genasar /
and whane men of that place hadden knowe hi; thei senten in to al that cuntree and thei brouȝ ten to hi alle that hadden syknesse /
and thei preieden hym that thei schulden touche the hem of his clothyng / and who eue tou chiden; weren maad saaf /
Thanne the scribis and the farisees ca men to hi fro jerlin; and seiden /
whi breken thi disciplis the tradicious of elde re men, for thei waischen not her hondis; whane thei eten breed /
he answeride and seide to hem / whi breken ȝe the maude ment of god for ȝoure tradiciou ⁝/
for god sei de / onoure thi fadir and thi modir / and he that cur sith fadir or modir die bi deth /
but ȝe seyn / who euere seith to fadir or modir what eue ȝifte is of me, it schal pfite to thee /
and he hath not worschipid his fadir or his modir / and ȝe ha maad the maundement of god voide; for ȝou re tradiciou /
ypocritis / ysaie the pphete p phesied wel of ȝou and seide /
this puple onou rith me with lippis; but her herte is fer fro me /
and thei worschipen me without cause; techynge the doccrynes and maudementis of men /
and whane the puple weren clepid to gidere to hym; he seide to hem / here ȝe and un durstonde ȝe,
thanne hise disciplis camen; and seiden to hi / thou knowist that if this word be herd; the pharisees be sclaudrid /
and he answeride; and seide / eueri plauntyng that my fadir of heuene, hath not plautide; schal be drawe up bi the roote /
suffre ȝe hem; thei ben bli de and lederis of blynde men / and if a blyn de man lede a blynde man; bothe fallen dou in to the diche /
petre answeride and seide to hi / erpowne to us this parable /
and he seide / ȝit ȝ ben withouten understondig ⁝/
un durstonden ȝe not that al thing that entrith in to the mouth; goith in to the wombe, and is sent out in to the goynge awei /
but tho thig that comenforth fro the mouth; goon out of the herte and tho thingis defoulen a man / for of the herte and tho thingis defoulen a man /
these thingis it ben; that defoulen a man / but to ete with hondis not waischen; defou lith not a man.
And jhr ȝede out fro then; and wente in to the coostis of tire and sidon /
and lo a woman of chananee ȝede out of tho cosstis; and criede and seide to hi / lord the so ne of dauith; haue merci on me / my douȝ ter is yeul trauelid of a fend /
and he answe ride not to hir a word / and his disciplis comen and preieden hym and seiden / leeue thou hir; for sche crieth aftir us /
he answeride and seide / I am not sent, but to the scheep of the hous of isra el; that perischiden /
and sche cam and worschipi de hym
and seide / it is not good to take the breed of children; and caste to houdis /
and sche seide / ȝhis lord / for whelpis eten of the crumes; that fallen doun fro the boord of her lordis /
thane jhr answeride and seide to hir / a woman thi feith is greet / be it doon to thee; as thou wolt / and hir douȝtir was heelid fro that our /
[ And wha ne jhr hadde passid fro thennes; he cam bisidis the see of galilee / and he ȝede up in to an hil; and sat the /
and myche puple cam to hi; and hadden wtih hem doumb men and crokid. and feble and blynde and manye othe; and thei castide doun hem at hise feet / andhe heelide hem,
so that the puple wondride seynge doumb me spe kynge and crokid goynge blynde men seynge; and thei magnefieden god of israel.

And jhu whane hise disciplis weren clepid togidere; seide to hem / I haue reuthe of the puple, for thei han now abiden there daies with me, and han no thing to ete / and I wole not leeue he fas tynge; lest thei failen in the weie /
and the disciplis seien to hi / wher of thanne so ma nye looues among us in desert; to fulfil le so greet puple /
and jhr seide to hem / hou many looues han ȝe ⁝/ and thei seiden / seue ne; and a fewe smale fisches /
and he comau dide th puple to sitte to mete on the erthe /
and alle eeten and weren fulfillide / and thei toke that was lefte of relifs; seuene leepis ful /
and thei that eten, weren foure thousynde of men; withouten litle children and wymen /
and whane he hadde lefte the puple; he wente up in to a boo, and cam i to the coostis of magedan /
And the pharisees and the saduceis camen to hi; teptynge / and preieden hym to schewe hem a tokene fro heuene /
and he answeride and seide to hem / wha ne the euentide is come ȝe seien; it schal be cleer / for heuene is rodi
and the morewtid; to dai tempest / for heuene schyneth heueli / thanne ȝe kune deme the face of heuene; but ȝe mou not wite the to kenes of tymes /
he wente forth.
And whanne hise disciplis camen ouer the see; thei forȝaten to take loo ues /
and he seide to hem / biholde ȝe and be war of the sourdeuȝ of pharisees and saduceis /
and thei thouȝten amonge he and seiden / for we han not take looues /
but jhr witynge; seide to hem / what thenken ȝe among ȝou of litil feith; for ȝe han not looues ⁝/
ȝit ȝe undursto de not neith haue mynde of fyue looues in to foure synde of men, and hou manye coffyns ȝe token /
neith of seuene looues in to foure thousynde of men, and hou manye ȝe token /
thanne thei undur stoden, that he seide not to be war of sour douȝ of looues; but of the techyng of pha risees and saduceis.
And jhr cam in to the par ties of cesarie of philip; and axide hise disci plis and seide / whom seyn men to me mann sone ⁝/
and thei seiden / sume joon baptist, othe helje; and othe jeremye, or oon of the pphetis /
jhr seide to hem / but whom seyn ȝe me to be ⁝/
symout petre answeride adn seide / thou art crist the sone of god lyuynge /
jhr answeride and seide to hi / blessid art thou symout bario na; for fleisch and blood schewide not to thee. but my fadir that is in heuenes /
and i seie to thee; that thou art petre and on this stoon I schal bilde my chirche / and the ȝatis of helle shulen not haue myȝt aȝen it /

and to thee I schal ȝyue the keies of the kyngdo of heuenes / and what eue thou schalt byde on erthe; schal be bounden also in heuenes / and what euere thou schalt unbynde on erthe; schal be unbounden also in heue nes.
Thanne he comaundide to hise dis ciplis, that thei schulden seie to no man, that he was crist /

fro that tyme jhr bigan to schewe to his disciplis; that it bihofte hym to go jerlm and suffre manye thingis, of the eldere men and of scribis and prynces of prestis, and be slayn and the thridde dai to rise aȝen /
and petre took hi and bigan to blame hi and seide / fer be it fro thee lord; this thing schal not be to thee /
and he tur nyde and seide to petre / sathanas go aftir me / thou art a sclaundre to me / for thou saue rise not thoo thingis that ben of god; but thoo thingis that ben of men.
Thane jhr seide to hise disciplis / if ony man wole come aftir me; deyne he hym silf and take his cros and sue he me /
he that wole make his lijf saaf; schal leese it / and he that schal leese his lijf for me; schal fynde it /
for mann sone schal come i glorie of his fadir with his aungels; and thanne he schal ȝelde to euy man aftir hi se werkes /
treuli I seie to ȝou, the ben su me of hem that stonden here; whiche shu len not taaste deth, til thei seen mann sone comynge in his kyngdom. ][
And aftir sire daies jhr took petre and james and joon his broth; and ledde hem a sides in to an hiȝ hil,
and was tur ned in to an othe lirnesse bifore hem / and his face sschoon as the sune; and hise do this weren maad whiȝt as snow /
and lo moises and elie apperiden to hem; spake with hi /
and petre answeride and seide to to jhu / lord it is good to us to be here / if you wolt; make we here there taberna clis / to thee oon, to moises oon, and oon to elie /
ȝit the while he spak; lo a briȝt dou de ouerschadewide hem / and lo a voice out of the cloude that seide / this is my derewor the sone, in whom I haue wel plesid to me; here ȝe hi /
and the disciplis herden and felden doun on her faces, and dredden gre tli /
and jhr cam and touchide hem; and seide to hem / rise up and nyle ȝe drede /
and thei liften up her iȝen; and saien no man but jhu aloone /
and as thei cam dou of the hil; jhr comaudide to hem and seide / seie ȝe to no man the visiou; til man sone rise aȝen fro deth.
And hise disciplis axiden hi and seiden / what thanne seith the scribis; that it bihoueth that elie come firste /
he answeride; and seide to hem / elie schal co me; and he schal restore alle thingis //
and I seie to ȝou, that elie is now comen, and thei kne wen hi not; but thei diden in hym what euere thingis thei wolden / and so man so ne schal suffre of hem /
thanne the disciplis undurstoden; that he seide to hem of joon baptist.
And whane he cam to the pu ple; a man cam to hym and fel doun on knees bifore hym and seide /
lord haue merci on my sone; for he is lunatik and suffrith yuele / for ofte tymes he fallith in to the fier; and ofte tymes in to the watir /
and I brouȝ te hym to thi disciplis; and thei myȝten not heele hi /
jhr answeride and seide / a thou gene raciou unbileueful and weiward; hou lon ge schal i be with ȝou, hou longe schal I suffre ȝou ⁝/ brynge ȝe hidur to me /
and jhr blamyde hi; and the deuel wente out fro hi // and the child was heelid fro that our //
Thanne the disciplis came to jhu pueli; and seiden to hi / whi myȝten not we caste hi out ⁝/

jhr seith to hem / for ȝoure unbi leue / treuli I seie to ȝou, if ȝe han feith, as a corn of seneuey; ȝe schulen seie to this hil, passe thou hennes and it schal passe. and no thing schal be unpossible to ȝou /
but this kynde is not caste out; but bi prei ynge and fastynge /
and whiles thei were abidyng togidere in galilee; jhr seide to he / mann sone schal be bitraied in to the ho dis of men
and thei schulen sle hi; and the thrid de dai he schal rise aȝen to lijf / and thei we ren ful sori.
And whane thei camen to capharnau; thei that token tribute came to petre and seiden to hym / ȝoure maistir pai eth not tribute /
and he seide / ȝhe / and whane he was comen in to the hous; jhr cam bi fore hi and seide / symount what semeth to thee, kyngis of erthe of whom taken thei tribute ⁝/ of her sones eith of aliens ⁝/
and he seide of aliens / jhr seide to hym / thane sones be fre /

but that we sclaundre he not, go to the see and caste an hook; nad take thilke fisch that firste cometh up / and wha ne his mouth is openyde; thou schalt fynde a statir, and ȝyue for thee and for me /
in that our the disciplis camen to jhu and seide / who gessist thou is grettir in the kyngdom of heuenes ⁝/
and jhr clepide alitil child; and putte hym in the myddil of hem
and sei de // I seie treuthe to ȝou, but ȝe be turned and maad as litle children; ȝe schulen not entre in to the kyngdom of heuenes /
thefor who eue mekith hym self as this litil child; he is grettir in the kyngdom of heuenes /
and he that resseyueth o sich litil child in my name; resseyueth me /
but who eue sclaudrith son of these smale that bileueth in me; it spe dith to hym that a mylnestoon of allis be hangid in his necke, and he be drenchid in the depnesse of the see.
Wo to the world for sclau dris / for it is nede that sclaudris come / ne theles wo to thilke man, bi whom a sclaudrith cometh /

and if thi hond or thi foot sclaudrith thee; kitte it of and caste awei fro thee / it is betere to thee to entre to lijf, feble eith cro kid, than hauynge tweyne hondis or twei feet to be sent in to euelastynge fier /
and if thyn iȝe sclaudre thee; pulle it out, and cas te awei fro thee / it is betere to thee with oon iȝe to entre in to lijf; than hauynge tweyne iȝen to be sent in to the fier of helle /
se ȝe that ȝe dispise not oon of these litle / for I seie to ȝou that the aungels of he in heuenes; seen euere more the face of my fadir that is in heuenes /
for mannn so ne cam to saue that thing that perischide //
what semeth to ȝou, if th weren to su ma an hundrid scheep and oon of hem hath er rid; wher he schal not leeue nynti and nyne in desert, and schal go to leche that that erride; /
and if he falle that he fynde it; treuli I seie to ȝou, that he schal haue joie th on mo re than ou nynti and nyuethat erride not /
so it is not the wille bifore ȝoure fadir that is in heuenes; that oon of these litil pe rische //
But if thi broth synneth aȝen thee; go thou and repue hi bitwixe thee and hi aloo ne / if he herith thee; thouhaa wonnen thi broth /
and if he herith thee not; take with thee oon or tweyne, that eueri word ston de in the inouth of tweyne or thre witnes sis /
and if he herith not hem; seie thou to the chirche / but if he herith not the chir che; be he as hethene man and a pupplica /
an to thee / I seien to ȝou treuli, what eue thingis ȝe bynden on erthe; thoo schule be bounde also in heuene /and what eue thigis ȝe unbynde i erthe; tho schulen be unboude also in heuene /
estesoone I seie to ȝou, that if tweyne of ȝou con tente on the erthe of eueri thing what euere thei aren, it schal be doon to hem, of my fadir that is in heuenes /
for whe tweyne or thre be gaderid in my name; the I am in the myddil of hem /
thane pe tir cam to hi and seide / lord hou ofte shal my broth synne aȝen me; and I schal for ȝyue hym ⁝/ wheth til seuene tymes ⁝/
jhr seith to hi / I seie not to thee til seuene sithis; but til seuentisithis seuenesithes //
Therfor the kyngdom of heuenes is lic ned to a kyng; that wolden rekene with hise seruautis /
and whane he bigan to rekene; oon that ouȝte teu thousynde talentis, was brouȝt to hi /
and whane he hadde not wher of to ȝelde; his lord comaudide hi to be seld and his wijf and children; and alle thingis that he hadde, and to be paiede /
but thilke seruaunt fel doun; and preiede hym and seide / haue pacience i me; and I schal ȝelde to thee alle thingis /
and the lord hadde merci on that seruaunt; and suf fride hym go and forȝaf hi the dette /
but thilke seruaut ȝede out; and foond oon of hise euene seruauntis, that ouȝte hym an hundrid pens / and he helde hym and strangli de hym and seide / ȝelde that thing that thou owist
and his euene seruaunt fel doun; and piede hi and seide / haue pacience in me; and I shal nuyte thee alle thingis to thee /
but he wolde not; but wente out and putte hi in to prisou til he paiede al the dette /
and his euene seruauntis seynge the thingis that weren doon; forewiden greth / and thei came and telden to her lord; alle the thingis that wer en doon /
thane his lord clepide hym; and sei de to hi / wickid seruaunt, I forȝaf to thee al the dette; for thou preiedist me /
thfor wher it bihouyde not also thee to haue merci on thi euene seruaunt, as i hadde merci on thee ⁝/
and his lord was wrooth, and took hym to turmentouris; til he pai ed al the dette /
so my fadir of heuenes, schal do to ȝou; if ȝe forȝyuen not eueri man to his broth of ȝoure hertis /
And it was doon whane jhr hadde endide these wordis; he passide fro galilee, and cam in to the coostis of judee ouer jordan /
and myche puple suede hi; and he heelide hem the /
and pharisees ca men to hi; temptynge hi and seiden / wher it be leueful to a man to leeue his wijf for ony cause ⁝/
which answeride and seide to hem / han ȝe not red for he that made men at the bigynnyng; made hem male and female ⁝/
and he seide / for this thing a man schal leeue fadir and modir, and he schal drawe to his wijf; and thei schulen be twey ne in o fleisch /
and so thei ben not now twei ne; but o fleisch / thefor a man departe not that thing that god hath joyned /
thei seien to hym / what thanne comaundide moises to ȝy ue a libel of forsakyng and to leue of /
and he seide to hem / for moyses, for the hardnesse of ȝoure herte; suffride ȝou to leeue ȝoure wy ues / but fro the bigynnyng it was not so /
and I seie to ȝou, that who euere leeueth his wijf but for fornycaciou and weddith an othe doith leccherie / and he that weddith the forsakun wijf; doith leccherie /
hise disciplis seyn to hi / if the cause of a man with a wijf is so; if spedith not to be wedded /
and he siede to hem / not alle men taken this word; but to whiche it is ȝouen /

for the ben gel dyngis, whiche be thus boren of the mo dris wombe / and th ben eldyngis; that be maad of men / and th ben geldyngis; that han geldid hem silf for the kyngdom of heuenes / he that mai take; take he //
Thanne litle children wern brouȝt to hi; that he schulde putte hondis to hem and preie / and the disciplis blameden hem /
but jhr seide to hem / suffre ȝe that litle children come to me; and nyle ȝe forbede hem / for of siche is the the kyngdom of heuenes /
and whanne he hadde put to hem hondis; he wente fro thennes.
And lo oon cam and seide to hym / good maistir, what good schal i do; that I haue euelas tynge lijf /
jhr seith to hi / what axist thou me of good thing ⁝/ th is o good god / but if thou entre to lijf; kepe the comaudemen tis /
he seith to hi / whiche / and jhr seide / thou schalt not do mansleyng, thou schalt not do a voutrie, thou schalt not do thef te, thou schalt not seie false witnessig /
worschip thi fadir and thi modir; and thou schalt loue thi neiȝbore as thi self /
the ȝonge ma seith to hi /I haue kepte alle these thigis fro my ȝougthe / what it failithto me /
jhr seith to hi / if thou wolt be parfit, go and selle alle thingis that thou hast, and ȝyue to pore men, and thou schalt haue tresoure in heuene, and come and sue me /
and wha ne the ȝonge man hadde herd these wor dis; he wente awei soreuful, for he hadde many possessious /
and jhr seide to hise disci plis / i seie to ȝou treuthe, for a riche man of hard schal entre in to the kyngdom of heue nes /
and estesoone I seie to ȝou, it is liȝter a camel to passe thorouȝ an edlis iȝe; than a riche man to entre in to the kyngdom of heuenes /
whane these thingis weren herd; the disciplis wondriden gretli and seiden / who thanne mai be saaf /
jhr bihelde and seide to hem / anentis men this thing is impossible //
Thanne petir answeride and seide to hi / lo we han forsake alle thingis; and we han su ed thee / what thanne schal be to us ⁝/

jhr seide to hem / treuli I seie to ȝou, that ȝe that han forsake alle thingis and han sued me; in the refeneraciou whane man sone schal sitte in the seete of his maieste, ȝe schulen sitte on twelue seetis demynge the twelue kynredis of israel /
and eueri man that for sakith hous brithen or sistren, fadir or mo dir, wijf eith children or feeldis for my na me; he schal take an hundridfold, I schal welde euelastynge lijf
( but manye schule be the firste; the laste / and laste; the firste /
The kyngdom of heuenes is lijk to an hosebonde man; that wente out firste bi the morewe, to hire werk men in to his vyneȝerd /
and whanne the couenaunt was maad with werk men, of a peny for the dai; he sente hem in to his vyneȝerd /
and he ȝede out aboute the thridde our, and say othe stondynge idel in the chepyng,
and he seide to hem / go ȝe also in to my vyneȝerd; and that that schal be riȝtful, i schal ȝyue to ȝou / and thei wentenforth /
estesoones he wente aboute the sixte our and the nynthe and dide in lijk maner /
but aboute the euleuenthe our he wente out, and foond othe stondynge, and he seide to hem / what stonden ȝe idil here al dai ⁝/
thei seien to hi / for no man hath hirid us / he seith to hem / go ȝe also i to my vyneȝerd /
and whane euenyge was come; the lord of the vyneȝerd seith to his procuratour / clepe the wer men; and ȝel de to hem her hire, and bigynne thou at the laste til to the firste /
and so whanne thei weren comen that camen aboute the eule uenthe our; also thei token euych of he a peny /
but the firste comen and demyden that thei schulden take more / but thei toke ech oon bi hem self a peny /
and in the ta kyng grurchiden aȝen the hosebonde ma;
and seiden / these laste mrouȝten oon our. and thou hast maad hem euene to us that ha⁝/ boren the charge of the dai and heete /
and he answeride to oon of he and seide / freend I do thee no wrong / wher thou hast not a cordid with me for a peny /
take thou that is thyn and go / for I wole ȝyue to this laste man; as to thee /
wher it is not leueful to me; to do that that I wille ⁝/ wheth thi iȝe is wickid for I am good ⁝/
so the laste schulen be the firste, and the firste; the las te / for manye ben clepid; but fewe ben chosen.
And jhr wente up to jerlm and took hise twelue disciplis in pryuytee and seide to hem /
lo we goon up to jerlm; and mann sone schal be bitaken to prynces and prestis and scribis, and the schulen condep ne hym to deth /
and their schulen bitake hi to hethene men; for to be scorned and scour gid and crucified / and the thridde dai he schal tise aȝen to lijf.
Thanne the modir of the sones of ȝebedee; cam to hym with hir sones honourynge and axynge sum thing of hym / and he seide to hir /
what wolt thou ⁝/ sche seith to hym / seie that these twei ne my sone sitte; oon at thi riȝthalf, and oon at thi lefte half in thi kyngdom /
jhr answeride and seide / ȝe witen not what ȝe axen / mou ȝe drynke the cuppe; which I schal drynke ⁝/ thei seien to hi / we mou /
he seith to hem / ȝe schulen drynke my cup the; but to sitte at my riȝthalf or lefte half, it is not myn to ȝyue to ȝou, but to whiche it is maad redi of my fadir //
and the ten herynge hadden indignaciou of the tweyne brithen /
but jhr clepide hem to hym and seide / ȝe witen that prynces of he thene men; ben lordis of hem / and thei that ben grettir; usen power on hem /
it schal not be so a monge ȝou / but who euere wole be maad grettir among ȝou; be he ȝoure mynystre /
and who euere among ȝou wole be the firste; he schal be ȝoure seruaunt /
as man sone cam not to be serued; but to serue / and to ȝyue his lijf redempciou for manye.
And whane thei ȝeden out of jerico; myche puple suede hym /
and lo twei blynde men, saten bisi dis the weie, and herden that jhr passide, and thei crieden and seiden / lord the sone of dauith; haue merci on us /
and jhr stood and clepide hem and seide / what wolen ȝe that I do to ȝou ⁝/
thei seien to hi / lord that oure iȝen be opened /
and jhr hadde merci on hem and touchide her iȝen / and anoon thei saien; and sueden hym /
And whanne jhr cam nyȝ to jerlm. and cam to bethfage at the mout of olyute; thanne sente he hise twei disci plis and seide to hem /
go ȝe in to the castel that is aȝen ȝou; and anoon ȝe schulen fynde an asse tied and a colt with hir / untie ȝe and brynge to me /
and if ony man seie to ȝou ony thing, seie ȝe that the lord hath no de of hem, and anoon he schal leeue hem /
al this was doon, that that thing schulde be fulfillide that was seid bi the pphete sei ynge /
seie ȝe to the douȝtir of sion, lo thi kyng cometh to thee mekli sittynge on an asse and a fool of an asse undur ȝok /
and the disciplis ȝeden and diden as jhr comaudi de hem /
and thei brouȝten an asse and the foo le and leiden the clothis on hem; and maden hi sitte aboue /
and ful myche puple; strewiden her clothis in the weie / othe kit tiden braunches of trees; and strewiden in the weie /
and the puple that wente bifore and that sueden; crieden and seiden / osanna to the sone of dauith / blessid is he that cometh in the name of the lord; osanna in hiȝ thingis //
And whanne he was entrid in to jerlm; al the citee was stirid and seide / who is this ⁝/
but the puple seide / this is jhr the pphete of naȝareth of galilee /
and jhr entride in to the temple of god; and castide out of the tem ple alle that bouȝten and seelden / and turnyde upso doun the boordis of chaugeris, and the chaieris of men that selden culueris /
and he seith to hem / it is written / inyn hous schal be clepid an hous of preier; but ȝe han maad it a denne of theues /
and blynde and crokid camen to hym in the temple; and he heelide hem /
but the pnces of pres tis and scribis seynge the meruelouse thigis that he dide, and children crynge in the tem ple and seiynge / osanna to the sone of da uith; hadden indignaciou
and seiden to hi / herist thou what these seyn / and jhr seide to hem / ȝhe / wher ȝe han neue red that of the mouth of ȝonge children of soukynge children; thou hast maad parfit heiynge /
and whane he hadde ledt hem; he wente forth out of the citee in to bethanye; and the he dwelte;
and tauȝte hem of the kyngdom of god / but on the morewe, he turnynge aȝen in to the citee; hungride /

and he say a fige tree bisidis the weie; and cam to it / and foond no thing the me; but leeues oneli / and he seide to it / neuere fruyt come forth of thee in to withouten ende / and anoon the fige tree was dried up /
and disciplis saie and wondriden seynge hou anoon it driede /

and jhr answeride and seide to hem / treuli I seie to ȝou, if ȝe haue feith, and douten not; not oneli ȝe schulen do of he fige tree / but also if ȝe seien to this hil take a caste thee in to the see; it schal be doon so /
and alle thingis what euere ȝe bileuynge shu len axe in preier; ȝe schulen take.
And whanne he cam in to the temple; the pryn ces of prestis and eldere men of the puple camen to hym that tauȝte and seiden / i wht power doist thou these thingis; and who ȝaf thee this power ⁝/
jhr answeride and seide to hem / and I schal axe ȝou oo word, the whi che if ȝetellen to me I schal seie to ȝou in what power I do these thingis /
of when was the baptym of joon; of heuene or of men ⁝/ and thei thouȝten withine hem self seiynge / if we seyn of heuene; thane he schal seie to us / whi thanne bileue ȝe not to hym ⁝/
if we seyn of men; we dreden the puple / for alle hadden joon as a pphe te.
and thei answeriden jhu and seiden / we witen not / and he seide to hem / neith I seie to ȝou; in what power I do these thingis //
But what semeth to ȝou / a man hadde twei sones; and he cam to the firste and seide / sone go worche this dai in my vyneȝerd /
he answeride and seide I nyle / but aftirward he forthouȝte; and wenteforth /
but he cam to the toth; and seide on lijk maner / and he answeride and seide / lord I go / and he wen te not /
who of the tweyne dide the fadris wille ⁝/ thei seien to hym / the firste / jhu seith to hem / treuli I seie to ȝou, for pup plicans and hoores schulen go bifore ȝou in the kyngdom of god /
