for joon cam to ȝou i the weie of riȝtwisnesse; and ȝe bileuen not to hi / but pupplicans and hoores; bileuyde / but ȝe saien and hadden no forthenkyng aft that ȝe bileuyden to hym //

here ȝe an othe parable / th was an hosebonde man that plauntide a vyneȝerd, and heggide it aboute and dalf a pressour th me, and bildide a tour / and hiride it to erthetilieris; and wente fer i pilgrymage /
but whane the tyme of fruy tis neiȝide, he sente hise seruautis to the erthetilieris; to take fruytis of it /
and the erthetilieris token hise seruautis; and beeten the toon, thei slowen an othe, and thei stonyden an othe /
estesoone he sente othe seruautis mo than the firste; and in lijk maner thei diden to hem /
and at the laste he sente his sone to hem; and seide / thei schulen drede my sone /
but the erthetilieris seynge the sone; seiden with me hem self / this is the eir / come ȝe sle we hym; and we schulen ha ue his eritage /
and thei token and castiden hi out of the vyneȝerd; and slowen hi /
thfor wha ne the lord of the vyneȝerde schal come; what schal he do to thilke erthetilieris /
thei seien t hym / he schal leese yuele the yuele men; and he schal sette to hire the vyneȝerd to othe erthetilieris is whiche schulen ȝelde to hi fruyt in her tymes /

jhr seith to hem / redde ȝe neuere in scripturis, the stoon wlnche bil deris repuyden; this is maad in to the heed of the cornere ⁝/ fo the lord this thing is doon; and it is meruelouse bifore oure iȝen /
thfor i seie to ȝou, that the kyngdom of god schal be ta ken fro ȝou; and schal be ȝouen to a folk doige fruytis of it /
and he that schal falle on this stoon; schal be broken / but on whom it schal falle; it schal alto brise hym /
and whane the prynces of prestis and farisees herden these parablis; thei knewen that he seide to hem /
and thei souȝten to holde hym; but thei dredde the puple, for thei hadden hi as a pphete /
And jhr answeride and spak estesoone in parablis to hem and seide /
the kyngdom of heuenes is maad lijk to a kyng that made weddyngis to his sone /
and he sente hise ser uautis to clepe men that weren bede to the weddyngis; and thei wolden not come /

estesoo ne he sente othe seruauntis; and seide / seie ȝe to the men that be beden to the feeste / lo I haue maad redi my mete my bolis and my volatils ben slayn and alle thingis be redi; come ȝe to the weddyngis /
but thei dispisiden; and wenten forth / oon in to his tou; an othe to his mar chonondise /
but othe helden his seruauntis, and turmentiden and slowen /
but the kyng whane he hadde herd; was wrooth / and he sente his oostis; and distriede tho manquelleris, and brente her citee /
thane he seide to hise seruautis / the weddyngis ben redi; but thei that weren clepid to the feeste weren not worthi /
thfor go ȝe to the endis of weies; and whom euere ȝe fyn den clepe ȝe to the weddyngis /
and hise ser uauntis ȝeden out in to weies; and gaderiden togidere alle that thei founden good ad yuel / and the bridalis was fulfillide with men sittynge at the mete /
and the kyng entride to se men sittige at the mete; and he sai the aman not clothid with bride cloth;
and he seide to hi / frend nou entridist thou hidur; without bride clothis / and he was doumb /
thanne the kyng bad his mynystris, bynde hym bothe hondis and feet; and sende ȝe hi in to utmer derknessis / the schal be wepige and gryntyng of teeth /
for manye ben clepis; but fewe be chosen /
Thanne the pharisees ȝeden awei and token a counsel; to take jhu in word /
and thei senden to hym her disciplis with erodians; and seien maistir we witen that thou art sothfast, and thou chargist not of ony ma / for thou biholdist not the persoone of men /
therfor seie to us; what semeth to thee / it is leueful that tribute be ȝouen to the empour eith man ⁝/
and whane jhr hadde knowe the wickidnesse of hem; he seide / ypocritis what tempten ȝe me ⁝/
schewe ȝe to me the prynte of the monee / and thei brouȝten to hym a pe nye /
and jhr seide to hem / thfor ȝelde ȝe to the empour; tho thingis that be of god /
and thei herden and wondriden / and thei leften hi; and wenten awei.
In that dai saduceis that seyn th is no risyng aȝen to lijf camen to hi; and axiden hym
and seiden / maistir moises seide / if ony man is deed, not hauynge a sone; that hise broth wedde his wijf; and reise seed to his broth /
and seuene brithen weren at us / and the firste weddide a wijf; and is deed / and he hade not seed, and lefte his wijf to his broth
also the secoude and the thridde til to the seuenthe /
but the laste of alle; the woman is deed /
but in risig aȝen to lijf; whos wijf of the seuene schal sche be ⁝/ for alle hadden hir /
jhr answeride and seide to hem / ȝe erren and ȝe knowen not scripturis ne the vertu of god /
for in the risyng asen to lijf. neith thei schulden wedde neith schulen be wed did; but thei ben as the aungels of god in he uene /
and of the risyng aȝen of deed men han ȝe not red that is seid of the lord, that seith to ȝou
I am god of abraham and god of isaac and god of jacob / he is not god of de ed men; but of lyuynge men /
and the pu ple herynge; wondriden in his techynge /
and pharisees herden that he hadde putte silence to saduceis, and camen togidere /
and oon of hem a techere of the lawe axide jhu and temptide hym /
maistir which is a greet maundement in the lawe ⁝/
jhr seide to hi / thou schalt loue thi lord god of al thi her te, and in al thi soule and in al thi mynde /
this is the firste and the moost maudement /
and the secoude is lijk to this / thou schalt loue thi neiȝbore as thi self /
in these twei mau dementis; hangith al the lawe and the pphe tis //
And whanne the farisees weren ga derid togidere; jhu axide hem
and seide / wht semeth to ȝou of crist; whos sone is he ⁝/ thei seien to hym / of dauith /
he seith to he / hou thanne dauith in spirit clepith his lord and seith /
the lord seide to my lord; sitte on my riȝthalf / til i putte thi enemyes a stool of thi feet /
thanne if dauith clepith hym lord, hou is he his sone /
and no ma myȝte answere a word to hym; neith ony man was hardi fro that dai do are hi more /
Thanne jhr spak to hte puple; and to hi se disciplis
and seide / on the chaiere of moyses; scribis and pharisees han sete /
thfor kepe ȝe and do ȝe alle thingis what eue thingis thei seien to ȝou; but nyle ȝe do aftir her werkis / for thei seien and doon not /
and thei bynden greuouse chargis and that mou not be boren and putten on schuldris of men; but with her fyngir thei wolen not moue hem /
thfor thei doon alle her werkis that thei be seen of men; for thei drawen abrood he filateries; and magne fien hemes /
and thei loue the firste sittige places in soperis and the firste chaieris in syna gogis;
and salutacious in chepyng and to be cle pid of men maistir /
but nyle ȝe be clepid mais ter; for oon is ȝoure maister / and alle ȝe be brithen /
and nyle ȝe clepe to ȝou a fadir on erthe / for oon is ȝoure fadir that is in he uenes /
neith be ȝe clepid maistris; for oon is ȝoure maistir crist /
he that is grettist a monge ȝou; schal be ȝoure mynystre /
for he that hiȝeth hi silf; schal be mekid / and he that mekith hym silf; schal be enhaunsid //
But woo to ȝou scribis and farisees and ipoctis; that closen the kyngdom of heuenes bifore me / and ȝe entren not; neith suffre men entrige for to entre /
woo to ȝou scribis and pharisees ypocritis that eeten the housis of widewis and preien bi longe preier / for this thing ȝe schulen take more doom /
wo to ȝou scribis and pharisees ipocritis that goon aboute the see and the lond; to make o proselite / and whanne he is maad; ȝe maken hym a sone of helle, double more than ȝe ben /
wo to ȝou blynde lederis that seien / who euere we rith bi the temple of god; it is no thing / but he that swerith in the gold of the temple; is dettour /
ȝe foolis and blynde / for what is gettir; the gold or the temple that halewith the gold /
and who euere swerith inthe auter; it is no thing / but he that swerith inthe ȝifte that is on the auter; owith /
blynde me for what is more the ȝifte, or the auter that halewith the ȝifte ⁝/
thfor he that swerith in the auter; swerith in it and in alle thigis that that be th on /
and he that swerith in the temple; swerith in it and in hym that dwel lith in the temple /
and he that swerith in heuene, swerith in the troone of god, and i hym that sittith th on /

wo to ȝou scribis and pharisees ipocritis that tipen mynte anete and comyn, and han lefte thoo thingis that ben of more charge of the lawe doom and merci and feith / and it bihofte to do these thingis; and not to leeue thoo /
blynde lederis clensyng a gnatte; but swolewynge a camel /
wo to ȝou scribis and pharisees ypocri tis, that clensen the cuppe and the plater with ourforth; but with me ȝe ben ful of rauey ne and undennesse /
thou blynde pharisee cle se the cuppe and the plater with me forth, that that is withoutforth be maad cleene /
wo to ȝou scribis and pharisees ipocritis; that be lijk sepulcris whitid / whiche without forth semen faire to men; but with me thei ben ful of boones of deed men adn of al fithe /
so ȝe withoutforth semen just to men; but wt me ȝe ben ful of ypocrisie and wickidnesse /
wo to ȝou scribis and pharisees ypocritis; that bilden sepulcris of pphetis, and make fair the biriels of just men,
and so ȝe ben in witnesig to ȝou silf; that ȝe ben the sones of hem that slowen the pphetis /
and fulfille ȝe the mesure of ȝoure fadris /
ȝe eddris and eddris briddis, hou schulen ȝe fle fro the doom of helle /
Therefor lo I sende to ȝou pphetis and wise men and scribis / and of hem ȝe shu len sle and crucifie, and of hem ȝe schulen scour ge in ȝoure synagogis, and schulen pursue fro citee in to citee;
that al the just blood come on ȝou that was schedde on the erthe fro the blood of just abel to the blood of ȝacharie the sone of barachie whom ȝe sloen bi twire the temple and the auter /
treuli I seie to ȝou, alle these thingis schulen come on this generaciou /

Jerlm jerlm that sleeft p phetis; and stonest hem that that ben sent to thee / hou ofte wolde i gadere togidere thi childre, as an henne gaderith togedere hir chikenes undur hir wyngis, and thou woldist not ⁝/
lo ȝou re hous schal be lefte to ȝou desert /
And jhr wente out of the temple / and hise disciplis camen to hym; to sche we hi the bildyngis of the temple /
but he answeride and seide to hem / seen ȝe alle these thigis ⁝/ treuli I seie to ȝou / a stoon schal not be lefte here on a stoon, that ne it schal be distried /
(and whanne he sat on the hil of olyuete; hise disciplis camen to hym pryueli and seide / seie us whane these thingis schulen be; and what tokene of thi comynge, and of the endig of the world /
and jhr answeride and seide to hem / loke ȝe that no man disseyue ȝou /
for manye schulen come in my name and schule seie I am crist; and thei schulen disseyue ma nye /
for ȝe schulen here barels and opynyous of batels / se ȝe that ȝe be not disturblid / for it bihoueth these thingis to be doon; but not ȝit is the ende /
folk schal rise togidere aȝen folk and rewne aȝen rewme, and pestilencis and hungris and erthemouyngis schulen be bi pla ces /
and alle these ben bigynnyngis of sore wis /
thanne men schulen bitake ȝou in to tribulaciou, and schulen sle ȝou, and ȝe schulen be in hate to alle folk for my name /
and thanne manye schulen be sclaudrid and bi traie ech othe and thei schulen hate ech othe /
and manye false pphetis schulen rise; and dis seyue manye /
and for wickidnesse schal be plenteuouse; the charite of many schal were coold /
but he that schal dwelle stabil in to the ende, schal be saaf / ][
and this gospel of the kyngdom schal be prechid in al the world, in witnessyng to alle folk; and thanne the ende schal come //
thfor whane ȝe se the ab homynaciou of discomfort, that is seid of daniel the pphete, stondynge in the hooli pla ce; he that redith undurstonde he /
thane thei that ben in judee; fle to the mouteynes /
and he that is in the hous roof come not dou. to take ony thing of his hous /
and he that is in the feeld turne not aȝen to take his coote /
but wo to hem that be with child and nouschen in tho daies /
preie ȝe that ȝoure fleyng be not maad in wyutir or in the sabath /
for thane schal be greet tri bulaciou, what maner hath not be fro the bigynnyng of the world to now neith schal be maad /
and but thoo daies hadden be a hrog gid; ech fleisch schulde not be maad saaf / but thoo daies schulen be maad schort; for chosen men /
thanne if ony man seie to ȝou, lo here is crist or the; nyle ȝe bileue /
if it mai be doon / lo I haue biforseid to ȝou /
thfor if I seie to ȝou lo he is in desert; nyle ȝe go out / lo in pryuy places; nyle ȝe twwe /
for as leit goith out fro the eest, and apperith i to the west; so schal be also the comynge of ma n sone /
where eueri thi bodi schal be; also the eglis schulen be gaderid thidur /
and anco aftir the tribulaciou of tho daies, the sune shal be maad derk and the moone schal not ȝyue hir liȝt, and the sterris schulen falle fro heuene, and the vertures of heuenes schulen be moued /
and thanne the tokene of mann sone shal appere in heuene, and thanne alle kyuredis of the erthe schulen weile in the cloudis of he uene; with myche vertu and maieste /
and he schal sende his aungels with a trupe and a greet vois; and thei schulen gadere hise chose fro foure wyndis / fro the hiȝest thingis of heuenes to the endis of hem /
and lerne ȝe the parable of a fige tree / whane his brau che is now tendir, and the leeues ben sprugen; ȝe witen that fomer is nyȝ /
so and ȝe whane ȝe se alle these thingis; wite ȝe that it is nyȝ in the ȝatis /
Treuli I seie to ȝou, for this ge neraciou schal not passe; til alle thingis be doon /
heune and erthe schulen passe; but my wordis schulen not passe /
but of thilke dai and our; not man woot, neith aungels of he uenes; but the fadir aloone;
but as it was in the daies of noe; so schal be the comynge of mann sone /
for as in the daies bifore the grete flood thei weren etynge and drynkige weddynge and takyng to weddyng to that dai that noe entride in to the schip,
adn thei kne wen not til the greet flood cam and took alle men; so schal be the comynge of man sone /
thane tweyne schulen be in a feeld; oon schal be taken and an othe lefte /
twei wymen schulen be gryngyng in o queerue; oon schal be taken and the toth lefte /
The text here differs from the standard text.tweyne in a bed; the ooon shal be taken and the toth lefte /
Therfor wake ȝe; for ȝe witen not in what our the lord schal come /
but wite ȝe this, that if the hosebonde man wiste i what our the theef were to come; certis he wolde wake, and suffre not his hous to be undurmyned /
and thfor be ȝe redi; for in what our ȝe gessen not, mann sone schal come /
Who guessen thou is a trewe seruaut and a prudent; whom his lord ordeynede on his meynee to ȝyue hem mete in tyme ⁝/
bles sid is that seruaunt whom his lord whane he schal come schal fynde lo doynge /
treuli I seie to ȝou, for on alle hise goodis; he schal ordeyne hym ][
but if thilke yuel seruaunt seie in his herte my lord tarieth to come,
and bigynneth to smyte his euene seruauntis and ete and drynke with drunken men;
the lord of that seruaunt schal come in the dai in which he hopith not, and in the our that he knowith not;
and schal departe hem, and putte his part with ipocryttis / there schal be wepig; and gryntig of teeth /
and fyue of hem weren foolis and fy ue prudent /
but the fyue foolis token her laumpis; and tooken not oile with hem /
but the prudent; token oile in her vessels with the laumpis /
and while the hosebond tariede; alle thei nappiden and slepten /
but at mydnyȝt a crie was maad; lo the spouse cometh go ȝe out to mete with hi /
thanne alle tho virgyns risen up; and araieden her laupis /
and the foo lis seiden to the wise / ȝyue ȝe to us of ȝoure oile; for ȝoure laumpis be quenchid /
the prudent answeriden; and seiden / left paraue ture and suffice not to us and to ȝou; go ȝe ra the to men that sellen and bie to ȝou /
and while thei wenten for to bie; the spouse cam / and tho that weren redi; entriden with hi to the weddyngis / and the ȝate was schitte /
and at the laste the othe vngyns camen and seidenThe text does not include "Lord, Lord, open to us". /
treuli I seie to ȝou; I knowe not ȝou /
25 :13 thfor wake ȝe; for ȝe witen not the dai ne the our // ][
for as a man that goith in pilgryma ge, clepide hise seruauntis, and bitook to he hise goodis /
and he that hadde fyue besautis we te forth and wrouȝt in hem; and wan othe fyue /
and he that hadde take tweyne; wan othe tweyne /
but he that hadde taken oon ȝede forth and dalf in to the erthe; and hid the monei of his lord /
but aftir longe tyme, the lord of tho seruauntis cam; and rekenyde with hem /
and he that hadde take fyue besauntis cam; and brouȝte othe fyue and seide / lord thou bitokist me fyue besauntis; lo I haue getu aboue othe fyue /
his lord seide to hym / wel be thou good seruaunt and feithful / for on fewe thigis thou hast be trewe; I schal ordeyne thee o manye thingis, entre thou in to the joie of thi lord /
and he that hadde taken twei talen tis cam and seide / lord thou bitokest me to me two besauntis; lo I haue wonen oue othe tweyne /
his lord seide to hym / wel be thou good seruaunt and trewe; for on fewe thingis thou hast be trewe / I schal ordeyne thee on manye thingis; entre thou in to the joie of thi lord / ][
but he that hadde taken o besaunt; cam and seide / lord I woot that thou art an hard man / thou repist where thou hast not sowe; and thou gaderist togidere, where thou hast not spred a brood /
and I dredige wente and hidde thi besaunt in the erthe / lo thou hast that that is thyn /
his lord answe ride and seide to hym / yuele seruaut and slowe, wistist thou that I repe where U sewe not; and gadere togidere where I spredde not a brood /
thfor it bihofte thee to bitake my money to chaungeris that whane I cam I schulde resseyue that that is myn with usu ris /
thfor take awei fro hym the besaunt; and ȝyue ȝe to hym that hath ten besautis /
for to eueri man that hath; me schal ȝyue; and he schal encreesse / but fro hi that hath not, also that that hym semeth to haue; schal be taken awei of hym /
whane mann so ne schal come in his maiestre, and alle hise aungels with hi; thane he schal sitte on the lege of his maiste,
and alle folkis schu len be gaderide bifore hym / and he schal de parte hem a twyne; as a schepparde depar tith scheep fro kidis /
and he schal sette the scheep on his riȝthalf; and the kidis on the lefte half /
thanne the kyng schal seie to hem; that schulen be on his riȝthalf / co me ȝe the blessid of my fadir; and take ȝe in possessiou the kyngdom maad redi to ȝou fro the makyng of the world /
for i hugri de; and ȝe ȝauen me to ete / and I thirstide; and ȝe ȝauen me to drynke / and was herbor les; and ȝe herboriden me /
nakid; and ȝe hi liden me / siyk; and ȝe visitiden me / I was in prisou; and ȝe camen to me /
and wha ne saien we thee herborles, and we herboride thee; or nakid and we hiliden thee ⁝/
for whane saien we thee siyk or in prisou; and we ca men to thee ⁝/
and the kyng answerynge schal seie to hem / treuli I seie to ȝou, as longe as ȝe diden to oon of these my leeste brithen; ȝe diden to me /
thane the kyg shal seie also to hem; that schulen be on his lefte half / departe fro me ȝe cursid in to euerelastynge fier; that is maad redi to the deuel and hise aungels /
for I hungride; and ȝe ȝauen not me to ete / I thirstide; and ȝe ȝaue not me to drynke /
I was herboreles; and ȝe herboriden not me / nakid; and kyueride not me / sijk and in prisou; and ȝe visitiden not me /
thanne and thei schulen answere to hi; and schule seie / lord whane saien we thee hungryuge or thirstynge or herboreles or nakid, or sijk or in prisou; and we seruyden not thee ⁝/
and these schulen go in to euerelastyng turment; but the just men schule go i to eulastige lijf /
And it was doon, whane jhr hadde en did alle these wordis; he seide to hi se disciplis /
ȝe witen that aftir twei daies pask schal be maad; and mann sone schal be bitaken to be crucified /
thanne the prynces of prestis and the eldere men of the puple were gaderid in to the halle of the prynce of ps tis, that was seid caiphas
and maden a cousel to hilde jhu with gile and sle hym /
but thei sei den / not in the halidan; left parauenture noise were maad in the puple /
and whane jhr was in bethanye in the hous of symout the leprouse;
a woman that hadde a box of alabastre of preciouse oynement cam to hym and schedde out on the heed of hi res tynge /
and disciplis seynge hadden dedeyn; and seiden / wher to this losse ⁝/
for it myȝte be seld for myche and be ȝouen to pore men /
but jhr knew and seide to hem / what ben ȝe heuy to this woman; for sche hath wrouȝt i me a good werk /
for ȝe schulen euere haue po re men with ȝou; but ȝe schulen not alga tis haue me /
this woman sendyng this oi nement in to my bodi; dide to birie me /
treuli I seie to ȝou where euere this gospel schal be prechid in al the world; it schal be seid that sche dide this in mynde of hi /
thane oon of the twelue, that was clepid judas sca rioth; wente forth to the prynces of pftis
and seide to hem / what wolen ȝe ȝyue to me; and I schal bitake hym to ȝou / and thei ordeynede to hi thritti pans of siluer /
and fro that tyme he souȝte oportunyte to bitraie hi /
and i the firste dai of therflooues; the disciplis came to jhu and seiden / where wolt thou we make redi to thee to ete pask /
jhr seide / go ȝe in to the citee to suman; and seie to hi. the maistir seith / my tyme is nyȝ; at thee i make pask with my disciplis /
and the disciplis diden; as jhr co maundide to hem, and thei maden the pack redi /
and whane euentide was come; he sat to mete with his twelue disciplis /
and he seide to hem as thei eeten / treuli i seie to ȝou; that oon of ȝou schal bitraie me /
and thei ful sori bigunen ech bi hym silf to seie / lord wher I am ⁝/
and he answeride and seide / he that puttith with me his hond in the plater; schal bitraie me /
forsothe mann sone goith; as it is wri ten of hi / but wo to that man; bi who man sone schal be bitraied / it were good to hym; if that man hadde not be boren /
but judas that bitraide hi; answerife seiynge / maist wher I am ⁝/ jhr seide to hym / thou hast seid /
and while thei soupiden; jhr took breed and blesside and brak and ȝaf to hise disciplis; and seide / take ȝe and ete; this is my bodi /
and he took the cuppe, and dide thankyngis and ȝaf to hem and seide / drynke ȝe alle her of /
this is my blood of the newe testament; which schal be sched for manye in to remyssiou of synnes /
and I seie to ȝou / I schal not drynke fro this tyme of this fruyt of the vyne, in to that dai whane I schal drynke it newe with ȝou in the kig dom of my fadir /
and whane the ympne was seid; thei wenten out in to the mout of oly uete /
thanne jhr seide to hem / alle ȝe schu len suffre sclaundre in me; in this nyȝt / for it is writen / I schal smyte the schepparde; and the scheep of the flok schulen be scaterid /
but aftir that I schal rise aȝen; I schal go bi fore ȝou in to galilee /
petre answeride; and seide to hi / thouȝ alle schulen be sclaudrid in thee; I schal neue be sclaundrid /
jhr sei de to hym / treuli I seie to thee, for in this nyȝt bifore the cok crowe; thries thou schalt denye me /
petre seide to hi / ȝhe thouȝ it bi houe that i die with thee; I schal not denye thee / also alle the disciplis seiden /
thane jhr cam with hem in to a tou that is seid jessamy ny, and he seide to hise disciplis / sitte ȝe here; the while I go thidir and preie /
and whane he hadde take petir and two sones of ȝebe dee; he bigan to be heuy and sori /
thane he seide to hem / my soule is soreuful to the deth / abide ȝe here; and wake ȝe with me /
and he ȝedeforth alitil; and felde doun on his face, preiynge and seiynge / my fadir if it is pos sible; passe this cuppe fro me / netheles not as I wole; but as thou wolt /
and he cam to hise disciplis; and foond hem slepige / and he seide to petre, so / wher ȝe myȝten not oon our wake with me /
wake ȝe and preie ȝe; that ȝe entre not in to tempta ciou / for the spirit is redi; but the fleisch is sijk /
and estesoone he cam and foond hem slepige, for her iȝen weren heuyed /
and he lefte he and wente estesoone and preiede the thridde ty me and seide the same word /
thanne he cam to hise disciplis; and seide to hem / slepe ȝe now; and reste ȝe / lo the our hath neiȝid, and manne sone schal be taken; in to the hon des of synneris /
rise ȝe go we / lo he that schal bitake me; is nyȝ /
ȝit the while he spak; lo judas oon of hte twelue cam, and with hym a greet cumpanye with swerfis and battis sent fro prynces of prestis, and fro the eldere men of the puple /
and he that bitraiede hym; ȝaf to hem a tokene, and seide / whom eue I kisse; he it is holde ȝe hi /
and anoon he cam to jhu and seide / heil maistir / and he kisside hi /
and jhr seide to hi / frend wher art thou comen / thanne thei camen nyȝ, and leiden hondis on jhu;
and helden hi / and lo oon of hem that weren with jhu, streiȝte out his hond, and drow out his swerd and he smot the seruaunt of the prynce of ps tis and kit of his eere /
thane jhr seide to hi / turne thi swerd in to to his place, for alle that taken swerd, schulen perische bi swerd /
wher gessist thou that I mai not preie my fa dir, and he schal ȝyue to me now mo than twelue legious of aungels ⁝/
you thane shul den the scriptures be fulfillide ⁝/ for so it biloueth to be doon /
In that our jhr seide to the puple / as to a theef ȝe han goon out; wt swerdis and battis to take me / dai bi dai I sat among ȝou and tauȝte in the temple, and ȝe helden me not /
but al this thing was doon; that the scripturis of pphetis schulden be fulfillide / thanne alle the disciplis fledden; and leften hi /
and thei helden jhu, and ledde hi to caiphas the prynce of prestis; whe re the scribis and farisees and the eldere men of the puple weren comen togidere /
but petre suede hym a fer in to the halle of the pryn ce of prestis; and he wente in, and sat with the seruauntis to se the ende /
and the prynce of prestis and al the councel souȝten false wit nessyng aȝen jhu; that thei schulen take hi to deth /
and thei fouden not; whane ma nye falst witnessis weren comen / but at the laste, twei false witnessis camen
and seide this seide / I mai distrie the temple of god; and aftir the thridde dai bilde it aȝen /
and the prynce of prestis roos and seide to hi / ans werist thou no thing to thoo thingis that these witnessen aȝen thee ⁝/
but jhu was stille / and hte prynce of prestis seide to hym / I co iure thee bi lynynge god / that thou seie to us if thou art crist the sone of god /
jhr seide to hym / thou hast seid / netheles I seie to ȝou fro henes forth ȝe schulen se man sone sit ynge at the riȝthalf of the vertu of god; and comynge in the cloudis of heuene /
thane the prynce of prestis torente hise clothis; and seide / he hath blasphemed / what ȝit han we nede to witnessis ⁝/ lo now ȝe han herd blasphemye /
what semeth to ȝou ⁝/ and thei answeriden and seiden / he is gilti of deth /
tha ne thei spetten in to his face, and smote hi with buffatis / othe ȝauen strokes with the pawme of her hondes in his face and
seide / thou crist a rede to us, who is he that smoot thee ⁝/
and petre sat withouten in the halle; and a damesele cam to hym and seide / thou were with jhu of galilee /
and he denyede bifore alle men; and seide / I woot not what thou seist /
and whane he ȝede out at the ȝa te, an othe damesele sai hym; and seide to he that weren the / and this was with jhu of na sareth /
and estesoone he denyede with an ooth; for i knew not the man /
and a litl aftir, thei that stoden camen; and seiden to petre / treuli thou art of hem; for thi speche maketh thee knowen /
thanne he bigan to warie and to swere; that he knew not the man / and anoon the cok crewe /
and petirbithouȝte on the word of jhu that he hadde seid / bifore the cok crowe; thries thou schalt denye me / and ȝede out; and wepte bittirli /
But whanne the morewtid was come; alle the prynces of prestis and the eldere men of the puple, token councel aȝen jhu that thei schulden take hi to the deeth /
and thei ledden hym bounden; and bitoken to pi lat of pouce justice /
and seide / I haue synned bitrai ynge riȝtful blood / and thei seiden / what to us / bise thee /
and the prynces of prestis token the siluer; and seiden / it is not leueful to putte it in to the tresorie; for it is the prijs of blood /
and wha ne thei hadden take councel; thei bouȝten with it the feeld of a potter, in to biriyng of pilgryms /
herfor thilke feeld is clepid acheldemar
that was fulfillide that was seid bi ye pphete jeremye seiynge / and thei han taken thritti pans the prijs of a ma preiside, whom thei preisiden of the childre of israel,
and thei ȝauen hem in to a feeld of a pottere, as the lord hath ordeynede to me /
and jhr stood bifore the domesman / and the justice axide hym and seide / art thou kyng of jewis / jhr seith to hym / thou seist /
and wha ne he was accusid of the prynces of pstis and of the eldere men of the puple / he answeri de no thing /
thanne pilat seith to hym / herist thou not hou manye witnessyngis thei seie aȝen thee ⁝/
and he answeride not hym to ony word; so that the justise wondride gretli /
but for a solempne dai the justice was wont to de lyuere to the puple oon bouden whom thei wolden /
and he hadde thoo a famouse man bounden that was seid barabas /
thfor pilat seide to hem; whanne thei weren togidere / whom wolen ȝe that I delyuere to ȝou wher barabas or jhu that is seid crist ⁝/
for he wil te; that bi euye thei bitraieden hi /
and while he sat for domesman; his wijf sente to hi and seide / no thing to thee; and to that just man / for I haue suffrid this dai many thingis for hym bi a visiou /
forsothe the pnces of pstis and the eldere men couseliden the puple, that thei schulden axe barabas but thei schulde distrie jhu /
but the justice answeride and seide to hem / whom of the tweyne wolen ȝe be delyuerid to ȝou ⁝/ and thei answeriden / ba rabas /
pilat seith to hem / what thane schal I do of jhu that is seid crist / alle seien be he crucified /
the justice seith to hem / what yuele hath he doon ⁝/ and thei crieden more and seiden / be he crucified /

and pilat seynge that he pfitide no thing, but that the more noise was maad; took watir and waischide hise hondis bifore the puple and seide / I am gilt les of the blood of this riȝtful man / bise ȝou /
and al the puple answeride and seide / his blood be on us and on oure children /
thane he delyue ride to hem barabas; but he took to he jhu to be crucified /
thanne knyȝtis of the maise token jhu in the moot halle; and gaderiden to hym alle the cumpenye of knyȝtis /
and thei unclothiden hym, and diden aboute hi a reed mantil /
and thei foldynge a crowne of thor nes and putten on his heed; and areked in his riȝthond / and thei thei kneliden bifore hym; and scorneden hym and seiden / hail kig of jewis /
and thei spetten on hym; and toke a rehed and smoote his heed /
and aftir that thei hadden scorned hym; thei unclothide hi of the mantil, and thei clothiden hym with hi se clothis, and ledden hym to crucifien /
and as thei ȝeden out; thei founden a man of arenen comynge fro the tou, symout bi name / thei constreyneden hym to take his cros /
and thei camen in to a place; that is clepid golgatha that is the place of caluarie /
and thei ȝauen hi to drynke wynd meynd with galle / and whane he had de taastid; he wolde not drynke /

and aftir that thei hadden crucified hym; thei departiden his clothis and kesten lot / to fulfille; that is seid bi the pphete seiynge / thei partiden to hem my clothis; and on my cloth thei keste lot /
and thei saten and kepten hi,
and setten aboue his heed his cause writen / this is jhu of naȝareth kyng of jewis /
thanne tweyne theeues weren crucified with hym, oon on the riȝthalf and oon on the lefte half /
and men that passiden forth blasphemyden hi; mo nynge her heedis
and seiynge / uath to thee that distriest the temple of god; and in the thridde dai bildist it aȝen / saue thou thi self / if thou art the sone of god; come dou of the cros /
also and prynces of prestis fror nynge with scribis and eldere men; seide /
for he tristide i god; delyue re he hi now if he wole / for he seide / that I am goddis sone /
and the theeues that weren crucified with hym upbraididen hi of the same thing /
but fro the firte our derknessis weren maad on al the erthe; to the nynthe our /
and aboute the nynthe our; jhr criede with a greet vois and seide / hely hely lamaȝabathanye, that is my god my god, whi hast thou forsake me /
and sumen that stoden the and heryne; seide / this clepid elie /
and anoon oon of hem re nynge; took and fillide a sponge with vyne gre / and puttide on a reede; and ȝaf to hi to drynke /
but othe seiden / suffre thou, se we wher helie come to delyuere hi /
forsothe estesoone jhr criede with a greet vois and ȝaf up the goost /
and lo the veil of the tem ple was torent in to twei parties fro the hiȝest to the lowest / and the erthe schook and stoones weren doue,
and biriels weren openyde, and manye bodies of seyutis that hadden slepte; risen up /
and thei ȝeden out of her biriels; and aftir his resurec ciou; thei camen in to the hooli citee; and ap periden to manye /
and the centurien and thei that weren with hym kepynge jhu wha thei saien the erthe schakyng and tho thigis that weren doon; thei dredden gretli and seiden / verili this was goddis sone /
and the weren the many wymen a fer; that suede jhu fro galilee; and mynystriden to hym /
a mong whiche was marie mawdelen and ma rie the modir of james and of joseph; and the modir of ȝebedees sones /
but whane the euenynge was come; the cam a riche ma of aramathie joseph bi name, and he was a disciple of jhu /
he wente to pilat; and axide the bodi of jhu / thane pilate comau dide the bodi to be ȝouen /
and whane the bodi was taken; joseph lappide it in a cleene sendel,
and leide it in his newe biriel that he hadde hewen it in a stoon / and he wa lewide a greet stoon to the dore of the biriel; and wente awei /
but marie mawdelen and an othe marie weren the; sittynge aȝen the sepulcre /
And on the toth dai that is afr pask euene; the prynces of prestis and the pharisees camen togidere to pilat
and sei den / sire we han mynde that thilke gilour seide ȝit lyuynge; aftir thre daies I schal rise aȝen to lijf /

thfor comaude thou that the sepulcre be kept in to the thridde dai / lest hise disciplis comen and stelen hi; and seien to the puple, he hath rise fro deth / and the laste errour schal be worse than the formere /
pilat seide to hem / ȝe han the kepyng / go ȝe; kepe ȝe as ȝe kunen /
and thei ȝedenforth and kepten the sepulcre; markyng the stoon with keperis /
But in the euentid of the sabath that bi gymeth to schyne in the firste dai of the woke, marie mawdelen cam and on othe marie to se the sepulcre /
and lo the was ma ad a greet erthe schakyng / for the aungel of the lord cam dou fro heuene; and neiȝide and turnyde awei the stoon, and sat th on /
and his lokyng was as leit; and hise clothis as snow /
and for drede of hym the keperis weren a feerd; and thei weren maad as deed men /
but the aungel answeride and seide to the wyme / nyle ȝe drede / for I woot that ȝe seken jhu that was crucified /
he is not here / he is risu; as he seide / come ȝe and se ȝe the place; whe re the lord was leid /
and go ȝesoone, and seie to hise disciplis; that he is risu and lo he sch al go bifore ȝou in to galilee / the ȝe schule se hym; lo I haue biforseid to ȝou /
And thei wenten out soone fro the biriels with drede and greet joie; remynge to telle to his disciplis /
and lo jhr mette hem; and seide / heil ȝe / and thei neiȝiden and helden hise feet and worschipiden hym /
thanne jhr seide to hem / nyle ȝe drede / go ȝe, telle ȝe to my brithen that thei go in to galilee; the thei schulen se me /
and whane thei weren goon; lo sume of the keperis camen in to the citee, and telde to the prynces of prestis, alle thingis that weren doon /
and whane thei weren gade rid to gidere with the eldere men and hadde take her councel; thei ȝauen to the kuyȝtis myche monei,
and seiden / seie ȝe that hise dis ciplis camen bi nyȝt; and han stole hi whi le ȝe slepten /
and if this be herd of the jus tice; we schulen cousele hym and make ȝou siker /
and the euleue disciplis wente in to galilee, in to an hil where jhr hadde ordeyned to hem /
and thei saien hym; and worschipiden / but sume of hem doutiden /
and jhr cam nyȝ; and spak to hem and seide / al power in heuene and in erthe is ȝouen to me /
thfor go ȝe and teche al le folkis; baptisynge hem in the name of the fadir and of the sone and of the hooli goost /
techynge hem to kepe alle thingis; what euere thingis I haue comaundide to ȝou / and lo I am with ȝou in alle daies; in to the endyng of the world /
